Begrunnelse: Akutt mekanisk korsryggsmerte uten nevrologiske funn. Kemp-positiv tyder på fasettleddsaffeksjon.

Beskriv Hvem rammes av hallux valgus? for Hallux Valgus (Knokkeltopp).

Hvem rammes av hallux valgus?

 

 Hallux valgus er den vanligste feilstillingen i forfoten og rammer omtrent 19% av befolkningen. Prevalensen Øker med alderen til ca. 36% hos de over 65 Ør.

 Kvinner rammes 2-3 ganger oftere enn menn, trolig på grunn av en kombinasjon av genetiske faktorer og bruk av trange sko og høye heler.

 
 
 19%
 av befolkningen rammes
 

 
 36%
 prevalens over 65 Ør
 

 
 2-3x
 oftere hos kvinner
 

 
 63-90%
 arvelighetskomponent
You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain Metatarsalgia to a patient.

Do you feel a burning, aching pain under the forefoot when walking? Does it feel like you're walking on
 pebbles? These are typical signs of metatarsalgia - one of many foot and
 ankle conditions we treat.

 Metatarsalgia is one of the most common causes of forefoot pain and affects everyone from runners to
 those who work standing for long periods. The good news is that most people improve
 significantly with conservative treatment.

Describe Prevention for Hip Sports Injuries.

Prevention

 

 
 Adequate warm-up: Minimum 15-20 minutes before intense activity

 Progressive load increase: Don't increase volume/intensity more than
 10% per week

 Strength training: Focus on hip muscles, especially adductors and
 gluteus

 Mobility: Maintain good hip mobility in all planes

 Recovery: Adequate rest between intense sessions

 Nutrition: Adequate energy intake and protein for tissue repair

 

 
 Copenhagen Adductor Protocol

 A specific exercise that has been shown to reduce groin injuries by up to 41% in
 football. The exercise is done in a side-lying position where a partner holds the top
 leg, and the athlete lifts the body up with the bottom leg. Start with 2x5 repetitions
 and gradually increase to 3x15.

Vanligvis ikke. En grundig klinisk undersøkelse er ofte tilstrekkelig for å stille diagnose og starte behandling. Billeddiagnostikk vurderes kun ved mistanke om alvorlig skade eller hvis plagene ikke ...

What is the prognosis for BPPV (Crystal Disease)?

Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

Forklar Bittfeil og Kjevesmerter for en pasient.

Mange pasienter kommer til oss med en bekymring: "Kan bittet mitt våre årsaken til smertene?" Kanskje har tannlegen nevnt overbitt, eller du har lest at skjev tannstilling gir hodepine. Det er forståelig å tenke slik - men hva sier egentlig forskningen?

 Kort fortalt: Sammenhengen mellom bittproblemer og kjevesmerter er betydelig svakere enn mange tror. En systematisk oversikt fra 2017 i Journal of Oral Rehabilitation gjennomgikk 25 studier og fant at kun 2 av 40 undersokte okklusale faktorer hadde konsistent sammenheng med kjeveleddsplager.

Describe symptoms of trigger points for Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm.

Symptoms of trigger points

 How to recognize trigger points in arm and forearm
 Tender knots: Palpable, tender points in muscles

 Referred pain: Pain that radiates to other areas

 Tightness: Reduced mobility in the muscle

 Weakness: Reduced strength without muscle damage

 Autonomic symptoms: Local sweating, goosebumps, redness

 Tingling/numbness: Can resemble nerve irritation

 Difference from nerve entrapment

 Trigger Points 
 Nerve Entrapment 

 Tender points in muscle 
 Pain along nerve distribution 

 Referred pain follows muscle patterns 
 Symptoms follow dermatomes 

 Pressure on point reproduces pain 
 Neural tension tests are positive 

 No real neurological deficits 
 May have true weakness and reflex changes

Beskriv Bør jeg unngå all aktivitet? i kontekst av Kalkskulder: Alt du trenger å vite.

Bør jeg unngå all aktivitet?

 Nei. I akutt fase bør du unngå bevegelser som provoserer smerte, men fullstendig hvile anbefales ikke. Tilpasset aktivitet innenfor smertefrie grenser hjelper med å opprettholde bevegelighet.

Describe What Is Lumbago? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Lumbago?

 

 
 Lumbago is what most people have when their back "locks up". The medical term is acute lumbago or non-specific low back pain. The pain comes suddenly, often after an awkward movement, lift or twist - but can also occur seemingly without reason.
 

 
 Characteristics of lumbago:

 
 Localized pain in the lower back

 Pain may radiate diffusely to the buttocks or thighs, but never below the knee

 Stiff back with limited mobility

 Worst in the first few days, then gradual improvement

 No tingling, numbness or muscle weakness

 
 

 
 With lumbago, no specific structural cause is found. MRI or X-ray often shows "normal" age-related changes that don't explain the pain. This is actually good news: it means your body isn't damaged.
 

 
 Most people improve significantly within 6 weeks. Pain scores typically fall from around 56/100 to 26/100 during this period (Pengel et al., BMJ 2003). However, we must be honest: 33-73% experience recurrence within one year, and some develop chronic symptoms.

Red flags for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck?

SEEK MEDICAL ATTENTION IMMEDIATELY FOR
 Walking difficulties or unsteadiness (signs of myelopathy)

 Symptoms in both arms or legs simultaneously

 Clumsiness in hands - difficulty with fine motor skills (buttoning)

 Bladder or bowel dysfunction

 Rapidly increasing weakness in arm or hand

 Fever combined with neck pain

 Unexplained weight loss or known cancer

 Nighttime pain that is not relieved by position changes

 These signs may indicate cervical myelopathy (spinal cord involvement) or
 other serious conditions requiring prompt evaluation.

Hva forårsaker Scheuermanns sykdom?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Den eksakte Årsaken er ikke fullstendig forstått, men flere faktorer ser ut til å spille inn:

 
 Hovedfaktorer

 
 Genetikk (vanligst): Med 74% arvelighet er genetiske faktorer den dominerende risikofaktoren. Tilstanden går ofte i familier.

 Mekanisk belastning: Teori om traction apophysitis - drag på vekstplatene under rask vekst.

 Vaskulare faktorer: Mulig nedsatt blodtilførsel til deler av virvlene under vekst.

 Biomekaniske forhold: Stram muskulatur i baksiden av lærene (hamstrings) kan forsterke belastningen.

 
 

 
 Viktig å vite

 Scheuermanns sykdom skyldes IKKE dårlig holdning - det er en strukturell tilstand, ikke et resultat av vaner.

Pasient spør: "Kan jeg trene med skuldersmerter?"

Ja, tilpasset trening er som regel anbefalt selv med skuldersmerter. Nokkelen er riktig dosering: start med isometriske ovelser (uten bevegelse) og graduer opp. Unnga ovelser som provoserer skarp eller utstraelende smerte. Konsulter helsepersonell hvis du er usikker.

Describe diagnosis for Cervical Myelopathy.

Diagnosis

 Neurological examination

 A thorough neurological examination is the first step. The clinician tests reflexes, muscle strength, sensation, gait pattern, and specific myelopathy signs (Hoffman, Babinski, clonus). The findings raise suspicion of the diagnosis, but imaging is necessary for confirmation.

 mJOA scale (modified Japanese Orthopaedic Association)

 The most widely used classification method for severity (Tetreault et al., Global Spine J 2017)
 Severity 
 mJOA score 
 Recommended action 

 Normal 
 18 
 None 

 Mild 
 15-17 
 Structured observation or surgery 

 Moderate 
 12-14 
 Surgery recommended 

 Severe 
 Below 12 
 Surgery strongly recommended 

 Imaging

 MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) — gold standard

 MRI is the most important investigation when cervical myelopathy is suspected (AO Spine guidelines). MRI shows
 Degree of spinal cord compression — how narrow the canal is

 T2 hyperintensity in the spinal cord — signal changes suggesting tissue involvement

 T1 hypointensity — a more serious sign that may indicate permanent changes

 Number of levels affected

 The cause — spondylosis, herniation, OPLL, or other

 CT and X-ray

 CT provides better visualization of bony structures and is useful for evaluating osteophytes and OPLL. X-ray can show degenerative changes, instability, and alignment of the spine, but cannot visualize the spinal cord directly.

 Important about T2 signal changes

 Changes in the spinal cord signal on MRI (T2 hyperintensity) are associated with poorer prognosis after surgery. The presence of both T2 hyperintensity and T1 hypointensity suggests more severe and potentially irreversible damage. This underscores the importance of early diagnosis .

Describe Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis) for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)

 

 Frozen shoulder is a condition where the joint capsule around the shoulder becomes thick, inflamed and tight. This leads to gradually increasing stiffness and pain. The condition goes through three characteristic phases:

 
 Freezing Phase (2-9 months)

 Gradually increasing pain and stiffness. Night pain can be intense.

 

 
 Frozen Phase (4-12 months)

 Pain decreases somewhat, but stiffness is at its worst. Daily activities become difficult.

 

 
 Thawing Phase (6-24 months)

 Movement gradually returns. Full recovery can take 1-3 years.

 

 
 Who gets frozen shoulder?

 Diabetes significantly increases the risk - diabetics have 5 times higher probability of developing frozen shoulder. Other risk factors are thyroid disorders and prolonged inactivity after injury or surgery.

 

 
 Prognosis: Although it takes time, 80% of patients regain good shoulder function with proper follow-up. Early treatment can reduce severity and duration.

Beskriv Hvordan Tekstnakke Påvirker Kjeven for Tekstnakke og Kjevesmerter: Hvordan Mobilbruk Påvirker Kjeven.

Hvordan Tekstnakke Påvirker Kjeven

 

 Sammenhengen mellom fremoverlent hode og kjeveplager er godt dokumentert:

 
 1. Biomekanisk Endring

 Når hodet skyves fremover:

 
 Underkjeven trekkes bakover og ned av tyngdekraften

 Kjevemusklene må jobbe for å holde munnen lukket

 Kjeveleddet belastes asymmetrisk

 Bakre del av leddet komprimeres

 
 

 
 2. Muskulær Kompensasjon

 
 Masseter og temporalis aktiveres unødvendig

 Konstant lav-nivå spenning fører til utmatting

 Økt risiko for triggerpunkter

 Spenningshodepine i tinninger

 
 

 
 3. Nerveforbindelser

 
 Trigeminocervical-komplekset kobler nakke og kjeve

 Stram nakkemuskulatur kan gi henvist smerte til kjeven

 Suboccipital spenning påvirker kjevemuskulaturen reflektorisk

 
 

 
 Forskning Bekrefter Sammenhengen

 Studier viser at 70-90% av TMD-pasienter har samtidige nakkeproblemer, og at behandling av nakken ofte forbedrer kjevesymptomene - selv uten direkte kjevebehandling.

Differensialdiagnoser ved Vestibulær Migrene: Når Svimmelheten Tar Over Livet?

Spontan rotasjonsvertigo (45%)

 Rommet spinner, varer typisk 1-4 timer. Så intenst at du ikke kan fortsette aktiviteter.

Posisjonsutløst svimmelhet (25%)

 Utløses av hodebevegelse, men varer i minutter til timer (ikke sekunder som ved krystallsyke ).

Visuelt utløst svimmelhet (40%)

 Forverres i travle visuelle miljøer (kjøpesentre, rulletrapper). Scrolling på skjerm trigger symptomer.

Beskriv Pauser og bevegelse for Hjemmekontor Ergonomi: Slik Unngår Du Vondt i Rygg og Nakke.

Pauser og bevegelse

 

 Selv den perfekte ergonomiske oppsetningen hjelper lite hvis du sitter stille i timevis. Kroppen er laget for bevegelse.

 
 30-minutters regelen

 
 Reis deg og beveg deg minst hvert 30. minutt

 Sett en timer eller bruk en app som påminner deg

 Bare det å reise seg og sette seg ned igjen har effekt

 
 

 
 Mikropauser

 
 Strekk nakken forsiktig fra side til side

 Rull skuldrene bakover noen ganger

 Strekk hendene og fingrene

 Gjør noen knebøy eller tåhev

 
 

 
 20-20-20 regelen for øynene

 Hvert 20. minutt: Se på noe 20 fot (ca. 6 meter) unna i 20 sekunder. Dette avlaster øyemuskulaturen og forebygger digital øyebelastning.

 

 
 Innbygg bevegelse i arbeidsdagen

 
 Ta telefonsamtaler stående eller gående

 Gå til et annet rom for å drikke vann

 Gjør 5 minutter med tøyeøvelser mellom møter

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.
Assess red flags: 48-year-old male, office worker with typical neck pain. During routine history reveals he started warfarin for new atrial fibrillation 4 weeks ago. INR level unknown.

URGENCY: MONITOR

No acute red flags, but IMPORTANT medication contraindication.

Clinical reasoning:
- Warfarin = anticoagulation = increased bleeding risk
- Spinal manipulation in anticoagulated patients carries risk of epidural hematoma
- INR unknown = could be in therapeutic or supratherapeutic range
- New warfarin (4 weeks) = INR may be unstable

This is NOT an acute emergency, but changes the treatment plan:

ACTION:
1. NO spinal manipulation (high-velocity techniques) until INR is known and stable
2. Ask patient to contact GP for INR measurement
3. Gentle mobilization and myofascial techniques can be used
4. Document medication use and adapted treatment plan
5. If INR <3.0 and stable: gentle mobilization OK. If INR >3.0: myofascial only.
Du er en erfaren kiropraktor-assistent. Hjelp med klinisk dokumentasjon, SOAP-notater og pasientkommunikasjon. Bruk norsk fagterminologi og følg ICPC-2 kodeverket.
Skriv SOAP for 2. konsultasjon etter akutt whiplash (7 dager etter ulykke).

S: 2. konsultasjon, 7 dager post-MVA. Pas. rapporterer smerte uendret (VAS 7/10). Hodepine persisterer (daglig, occipitalt). Ny symptom: Konsentrasjonsvansker. Søvn dårlig — våkner av smerter 3x/natt. Har vært sykmeldt. Bruker paracetamol 1g x4.

O: Cervikal ROM: Uendret fra baseline, fortsatt globalt redusert ~50%. Myofascial: SCM og trapezius like ømme. C2-C3 restriksjon vedvarer. Ny test: Cervikal fleksjon rotasjon test positiv V (indikerer C1-C2 dysfunksjon).

A: WAD grad II, 1 uke post-traume — stabil (ikke forverret, ikke bedret).
   Forventningsavklaring: Noen WAD-pasienter har forsinket bedring.
   Konsentrasjonsvanker monitoreres (mulig mild hjernerysting).

P: 1) Fortsatt forsiktig mobilisering (ikke manipulasjon i akuttfase)
   2) Myofascial frigjøring SCM, scaleni, suboccipitalt
   3) Hjemmeøvelser: Isometrisk nakkestyrking, gentle ROM
   4) SCAT6-screening ved neste konsultasjon (konsentrasjonsvansker)
   5) Neste time om 3-4 dager
   6) Forsikringsdokumentasjon oppdatert

Viktig

 Nattesmerte forekommer kun hos ca. 25% med Morton's nevrom. Dersom nattesmerte er fremtredende, bør andre diagnoser vurderes.

Describe symptoms for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Symptoms

 Typical symptoms

 Burning pain on the outer thigh

 Numbness - reduced skin sensation

 Tingling or prickling - "ants crawling"

 Hyperesthesia - hypersensitivity, pain with light touch

 Symptoms in a defined area - approximately 15x20 cm on the thigh

 Important characteristics

 Only sensory symptoms - never muscle weakness

 One-sided - usually affects only one thigh (in 80%)

 Worsens with standing/walking - improves with sitting

 No back or groin pain 

 Symptoms worsen with
 Prolonged standing

 Extended walking

 Hip extension (stretching hip backward)

 Tight pants or belt

 Lying on stomach

 Symptoms improve with
 Sitting - especially with bent hip

 Loose clothing

 Bending hip forward

 How to distinguish from other conditions?

 Meralgia paresthetica causes no weakness in the leg. If you have weakness in thigh
 or hip, the symptoms are likely from the spine or another nerve. Sciatica causes symptoms on the
 back of the leg, not the front. Pain on the outside of the hip can also be caused by
 GTPS/gluteal tendinopathy , while deep buttock pain may
 indicate piriformis syndrome .

Beskriv Første konsultasjon (ca. 45 minutter) i kontekst av Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Første konsultasjon (ca. 45 minutter)

 Ved første konsultasjon får du en grundig undersøkelse med:

 
 Sykehistorie og smertekartlegging

 Fysisk undersøkelse av kne, hofte og ankel

 Vurdering av bevegelsesmønstre og muskelstyrke

 Eventuell henvisning til bildediagnostikk hvis nødvendig

 
 

 Behandlingen tilpasses din tilstand og kan inkludere: leddmobilisering, bløtvevsbehandling, tøyning, dry needling, trykkbølgebehandling (for seneplager), og ikke minst å et individuelt Øvelsesprogram.

 
 HjemmeØvelser å nåkkelen til bedring

 Øvelser du gjør selv mellom behandlingene er avgjørende for resultatet. Typiske fokusområder:

 
 Quadriceps-styrke: Knebøy, utfall, step-ups

 Hoftemuskulatur: Gluteus-Øvelser, sideliggende beinhev, bridging

 Balanse og propriosepsjon: Ettbeins-stående, balansebrett

 Tøyning: Quadriceps, hamstrings, leggmuskulatur

Assess red flags: 60-year-old female, history of breast cancer 5 years ago, new thoracic pain T6, constant, elevated ALP.

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Suspected bone metastasis from breast cancer.

Findings:
- Previous malignancy (breast cancer - common source of skeletal metastases)
- New focal thoracic pain
- Elevated ALP (osteoblastic activity)
- Constant pain pattern

ACTION: MRI thoracic spine. Oncology consultation. Blood work including tumor markers. No manipulation at T6.

Hva er prognosen for Spenningshodepine: Alt du trenger å vite?

Prognose - hvordan går det?

 

 Episodisk spenningshodepine har generelt god prognose:

 
 
 75%
 fortsetter kun episodisk
 

 
 ~50%
 remisjon over 3 Ør
 

 
 15-25%
 utvikler kronisk form
 

 

 Risikofaktorer for kronifisering

 
 Medikamentoverforbruk (sterkeste prediktor)

 Samtidig migrene

 Søvnproblemer

 Depresjon og angst

 Stillesittende livsstil

 

 
 Realistiske forventninger

 Tilbakefall er vanlig, spesielt ved kronisk form. Behandling kan gi betydelig lindring og færre hodepinedager, men forebyggende tiltak (trening, stressmestring, gode vaner) må ofte opprettholdes for å holde plagene i sjakk.

Describe 7. Vestibular Neuritis in the context of Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

7. Vestibular Neuritis

 Prevalence: 3-10% in dizziness clinics

 Viral inflammation of the balance nerve causing sudden, intense dizziness lasting several days.

 
 Sudden onset, often after a cold

 Constant, intense vertigo for several days

 No hearing loss (distinguishes from labyrinthitis)

 10-15% develop BPPV afterward

 
 Read more about vestibular neuritis →

Differential diagnoses for Shoulder Impingement?

Neer's test

 The arm is passively lifted straight forward with internal rotation. Positive when pain occurs at end range. Sensitivity 75-89% , but specificity only 25-31% (Hegedus et al. 2012). The test catches most cases of impingement but also produces many false positives.

Hawkins-Kennedy test

 The arm is held in 90 degrees of flexion, and the forearm is rotated inward. Positive when pain occurs. Sensitivity 80-90% , specificity 25-50% (Hegedus et al. 2012). Considered the most sensitive single test.

Painful arc

 The patient actively lifts the arm out to the side. Pain between 60-120 degrees is positive. This test has somewhat better specificity than Neer and Hawkins alone.

You are a clinical communication assistant for chiropractors. Answer patient questions clearly and empathetically using correct medical terminology.
Patient asks: "Why should I avoid cortisone?"

Cortisone can provide short-term pain relief, but research shows it can weaken

Beskriv årsaker for Lumbal Foraminal Stenose.

Årsaker

 Foraminal stenose skyldes nesten alltid aldersrelaterte forandringer. De vanligste årsakene, rangert etter hyppighet
 Skivedeegenerasjon og høydetap: Når skiven mellom virvlene mister høyde, synker foramen sammen. Dette er den vanligste årsaken.

 Facettleddshypertrofi: Facettleddene bak i ryggen blir større og tar plass i foramen.

 Osteofytter: Beinpåleiringer (beinsporer) som vokser inn i foramen.

 Skiveprolaps eller bukling: Skivemateriale som presser inn i foramen.

 Degenerativ spondylolistese: Glidning av en virvel over den under.

 Ligamentum flavum-fortykkelse: Leddbåndet som strekker seg langs baksiden av spinalkanalen kan bli tykkere med alderen.

 Lumbal spinal stenose samlet rammer omtrent 4,9 % av voksne, stigende til 6,8 % etter fylte 50 og 9 % etter 70 (AME Medical Journal, 2022).

Describe symptoms - what si joint pain feels like for SI Joint Pain and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Symptoms - What SI Joint Pain Feels Like

 Pain Location

 The pain is usually located right over the SI joint - slightly to the side from the midline, just below
 the hip crest. Most experience one-sided pain localized to the area around or just below
 the posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS). In 94% of cases, the patient can point to the pain within 10 cm
 below and 3 cm lateral to the PSIS.

 Fortin's Finger Test - A Simple Self-Test

 Point with one finger to where it hurts most. Patients with SI joint pain typically point to an area
 within 1 cm of the posterior iliac spine. This test has shown 77% sensitivity and 100% specificity in
 studies.

 Referred Pain

 The pain can radiate to
 Buttocks (most common)

 Groin (14%)

 Back and outside of thigh (50%)

 Below the knee (28%) - but rarely further down

 Important: With pure SI joint pain, the pain usually doesn't go below the
 knee - unlike true sciatica/radiculopathy.

 Aggravating Factors

 Getting up from a seated position

 Walking stairs (especially up)

 Standing on one leg

 Turning over in bed

 Driving (asymmetric pedal use)

 Prolonged sitting or standing

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En Cochrane-oversikt fra 2007 gjennomgikk 23 studier med over 2300 deltakere. Hovedkonklusjonen var tydelig: Tidlig aktiv mobilisering er klart bedre enn hvile og nakkekrage.

 
 Vi bruker forsiktige teknikker tilpasset skadens fase:

 
 Mobilisering: Myke teknikker for å gjenopprette bevegelse i løste ledd. Ved akutt nakkesleng unngår vi kraftig manipulasjon.

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Behandling av stramme muskler som forsøker å "beskytte" nakken.

Describe treatment options for Headache on Top of the Head.

Treatment

 

 Treatment of headache on top of the head focuses on the underlying causes - especially neck structures and musculature.

 
 For Cervicogenic Headache

 Manual treatment has moderate evidence for short-term effect. A 2022 systematic review with 20 studies and 1439 patients found large effect on pain intensity in the short term compared to placebo.

 Important to note: At 12-month follow-up, manual treatment alone did not show better effect than placebo. Neck exercises, however, showed sustained effect.

 

 
 For Tension Headache

 Evidence for manual treatment is more limited. 2011 guidelines concluded that manipulation cannot be recommended for episodic tension headache, but that low-intensity mobilization may be useful for chronic problems.

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 
 Posture Correction

 Avoid forward head posture during screen work. Make sure the screen is at eye level and take regular breaks.

 

 
 Neck Exercises

 Gentle stretches and strengthening exercises for the neck have documented effect. Especially exercises that strengthen the deep neck flexors can be useful.

 

 
 Stress Management

 For tension headache, relaxation, mindfulness or other stress management techniques can help.

 

 
 Limit Pain Medication

 Avoid daily use of paracetamol or NSAIDs to prevent medication overuse headache.

 

 Treatment Course

 Dose-response studies for cervicogenic headache found that 8-10 treatments over 6 weeks was effective. For most patients, you can...

How is BPPV (Crystal Disease) diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made through medical history and clinical examination. The most important tests are:

 
 Dix-Hallpike Test

 The patient sits on the bench with head turned 45 degrees toward the suspected side, then is quickly laid back until the head hangs 20 degrees below the horizontal plane. With posterior canal BPPV, upbeating, rotational nystagmus is seen after a few seconds delay.

 

 
 Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

Beskriv Ekte isjias vs. falsk isjias for Isjias: Alt du trenger å vite.

Ekte isjias vs. falsk isjias

 

 Dette skillet er avgjørende for riktig behandling.

 Ekte isjias (lumbal radikulopati)

 Ved ekte isjias er det faktisk irritasjon eller kompresjon av nerveroten i ryggraden. De vanligste Årsakene, rangert fra hyppigst til sjeldnest:

 
 1. Diskusprolaps (~90% av tilfellene)

 Gelmassen fra skiven buler ut og trykker på nerven. Omtrent 95% av alle lumbale prolapser skjer på L4-L5 eller L5-S1 niva (StatPearls, 2023).

 
 
 
 

 
 2. Spinal stenose

 Trang ryggmargskanal, vanligere hos eldre. Kan gi bilaterale symptomer og forverres ved gange. Les mer om spinal stenose.

 

 
 3. Foraminal stenose

 Tranghet i nerveutgangen fra virvelsoylene. Ofte aldersbetinget slitasje.

 

 
 4. Spondylolistese

 Glidning av en virvel i forhold til en annen. Særlig vanlig ved L5-S1.

 

 Falsk isjias (pseudoiskias)

 Ved falsk isjias er nerven selv ikke i klem. Smerten refereres fra andre strukturer som etterligner isjiassmerte:

 
 1. Triggerpunkter og muskulære Årsaker (vanligst)

 Omme knuter i glutealmuskulatur, quadratus lumborum eller hamstrings kan gi referert smerte ned i benet.

 

 
 2. SI-leddsdysfunksjon

 Referert smerte fra bekkenbaksiden. Gir ofte smerte til setet og baksiden av læret.

 

 
 3. Facettleddssyndrom

 Referert smerte fra leddene mellom virvlene. Typisk forverret ved ekstensjon og rotasjon.

 

 
 4. Piriformis-syndrom (0,3-6% av tilfeller)

 Piriformis-muskelen i setet komprimerer isjiasnerven. Diagnosen er omdiskutert og anses...

Hva forårsaker Nummenhet i fingrene - Nakke eller hand??

HandÅrsaker

 

 Karpaltunnelsyndrom

 Den vanligste Årsaken til nummenhet i fingrene. Medianusnerven blir klemt i karpaltunnelen - en trang passasje i handleddet.

 
 Kjennetegn på karpaltunnelsyndrom

 
 Fingre påvirket: Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger, og halve ringfinger

 Verre om natten: Mange vakner av nummenhet og må riste på handen

 Lindres ved risting: å riste på handen gir ofte kortvarig lindring

 Ingen nakkesmerte: Symptomene er lokalisert til hand og underarm

 Risikofaktorer: Graviditet, diabetes, hypothyreose, repetitivt arbeid

 Svakhet: Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan tommelmuskulaturen bli svakere

 
 

 Ulnarisnerveaffeksjon (Cubitaltunnelsyndrom)

 Ulnarisnerven kan bli klemt ved albuen (cubitaltunnelen) eller ved handleddet (Guyons kanal).

 
 Kjennetegn på ulnarispåvirkning

 
 Fingre påvirket: Lillefinger og halve ringfinger (ulnare halvdel)

 Albueposisjon: Ofte verre ved bøyning av albuen eller ved å hvile på albuen

 Innsiden av handen: Kan gi svakhet i de små handmusklene

 "Klofingre": Ved alvorlige tilfeller kan fingrene få kloliknende stilling

 
 

 Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS)

 Nervene og blodarene til armen kan bli klemt i området mellom nakkebasis og armhulen.

 
 Kjennetegn på TOS

 
 Nummenhet og prikking i hele handen eller flere fingre

 Ofte forverret av å holde armene over hodet

 Kan gi kuldefølelse og fargeforandringer i handen

 Ofte forbundet med dårlig holdning eller ekstra nakkeribben

Describe When adaptation becomes pathology in the context of Thrower's Shoulder and GIRD: When Throwing Causes Shoulder Pain.

3. Muscular imbalances

 The throwing muscles (anterior shoulder, chest muscles) often become stronger than the posterior
 stabilizers, reinforcing the imbalance.

 

 When adaptation becomes pathology

 When the posterior capsule becomes too tight, the rotation center in the shoulder shifts. This can lead
 to:

 
 Internal impingement: Rotator cuff tendons are pinched between the humeral head and
 labrum posterosuperiorly

 SLAP lesion: Traction pain at the biceps attachment
 

 Partial rotator cuff tear: Especially the undersurface of supraspinatus

 

 
 Risk factors for developing symptomatic GIRD

 
 Rapid increase in training volume or intensity

 Lack of periodization and recovery

 Insufficient warm-up

 Neglecting stretching and posterior strength

 Poor throwing technique

Du er en rask klinisk tekstassistent. Generer korte, presise kliniske oppsummeringer for kiropraktisk dokumentasjon.
Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Hofteovelser og bekkentrening.

Hvorfor hofteovelser er viktig: Hofteleddet kobler overkroppen til underkroppen og er involvert i nesten alt du gjor - fra a ga og sta til a sitte og boye deg. Nar hoftemuskulaturen er svak eller stiv, ma andre strukturer kompensere. Det er derfor svake hoftemuskler ofte gir plager i bade korsrygg og kne.

Mobiliseringsovelser for hoften: Mobiliseringsovelser gjenoppretter bevegelighet i hofteleddet og reduserer stivhet. Gjor disse daglig, gjerne som morgenrutine. Alle ovelsene gjores i rolig tempo uten a presse gjennom smerte.

Styrkeovelser for hofte og sete: Styrkeovelser er selve fundamentet i hofte-rehabilitering. Forskning viser at ekstern motstand oker gluteal muskelkraft med 28-150 N sammenlignet med kroppsvekt alene (Frontiers, 2025). Start med kroppsvekt og legg til strikk eller vekter etter hvert.

Toyningsovelser: Toyning bidrar til a opprettholde fleksibilitet og redusere muskulaer spenning rundt hoften. Forskningsbasert anbefaling er a holde hver strekk i 30-60 sekunder, med 2-3 repetisjoner (flere SR, 2020+).

Bekkenbunn og dyp stabilisering: Bekkenbunnsmuskulaturen og de dype stabilisatorene jobber sammen med hoftemusklene for a holde bekkenet stabilt. Forskning viser at gluteale muskler og adduktorer er synergister med bekkenbunnen (JSAMS, 2024). Disse ovelsene er sarlig viktige etter fodsler og ved SI-ledd-plager .

Ovelser for spesifikke tilstander: Ulike hofteplager krever ulike tilnarminger. Her er anbefalte tilpasninger basert pa din tilstand.

10-minutters daglig hofteprogram: Har du lite tid? Dette programmet dekker det viktigste pa bare 10 minutter. Gjor det daglig for a holde hoften mobil og sterk.

Tips for eldre og kontraindikasjoner: Hofteovelser er viktige for eldre for a forebygge fall og opprettholde selvstendighet. Her er noen tilpasninger

You are a clinical documentation specialist for chiropractic. Generate accurate, professional patient explanations using correct medical terminology.
Explain conservative treatment with a chiropractor for Lumbar Foraminal Stenosis.

Conservative Treatment with a Chiropractor

 Conservative treatment is the first choice for foraminal stenosis. All guidelines recommend trying conservative treatment for 3-6 months before considering surgery (AFP, 2024).

 Key Principle: Open the Foramen

 With foraminal stenosis, the treatment logic is opposite to what many are used to. While we often work with extension (backward bending) for common back pain, foraminal stenosis is about flexion - because forward bending opens the nerve canal.

 Manual Treatment

 Lumbar flexion mobilization (side-lying or supine)

 Lateral flexion away from the painful side

 Neural mobilization (gentle nerve gliding techniques)

 Soft tissue treatment for secondary muscle tension

 We avoid sustained extension and rotation toward the painful side

 Exercises (Flexion Program)

 Phase 1 (Weeks 1-4) - Symptom Management

 Double knee-to-chest in supine

 Posterior pelvic tilt

 Seated forward bend ("prayer position")

 Walking program (forward-leaning posture is natural and fine)

 Stationary cycling (seated in flexion)

 Phase 2 (Weeks 4-8) - Gradual Progression

 Bridge exercises with progression

 Core stability with flexion focus

 Hip strength (abductors, gluteus)

 Pool-based exercise

 Longer walks

 Phase 3 (Weeks 8-12+) - Functional Rehabilitation

 General strengthening program

 Functional activities with good body mechanics

 Maintenance program

 Strategies for managing flare-ups

 An important 2024 study showed that the severity of stenosis on MRI does not affect how well the patient responds to exercise (PMC, 2024). This means that even with moderate to severe stenosis, exercise-based rehabilitation can be effective.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 48-year-old female with symmetric swelling and pain in MCP joints (2nd-4th finger bilaterally) and PIP joints for 8 weeks. Morning stiffness 50 minutes. Fatigue. No previous joint problems.

URGENCY: REFER ROUTINE (within 2-4 weeks)

Suspected rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Clinical reasoning:
- Symmetric polyarthritis in MCP/PIP joints = classic for RA
- Morning stiffness >30 min = inflammatory pattern (mechanical: <30 min)
- Fatigue = systemic inflammation
- Onset age 48 = typical for RA (40-60 years)
- No acute danger, but EARLY treatment (within 3 months) gives significantly better long-term prognosis
- "Window of opportunity" = first 3-6 months are critical to prevent joint erosion

ACTION: Blood work (anti-CCP, RF, CRP, ESR, CBC). Rheumatology referral within 2-4 weeks. Chiropractic treatment of neck/back can continue. Do NOT manipulate swollen joints directly.

Describe causes and risk factors for Trigger Points and Myofascial Pain Syndrome in the Neck.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Trigger points develop when muscle fibers become overloaded or damaged. The most common causes
 Static loading and poor ergonomics

 Prolonged desk work, screen use with forward head posture, and repetitive work are by far the most common causes. Office workers have an average of 6 active and 10-11 latent trigger points.

 Muscular overload

 Repetitive movements, heavy lifting, or sudden increased training load.

 Stress and tension

 Psychological stress often leads to chronic muscle tension, especially in the neck and shoulders.

 Other factors

 Sleep problems and fatigue: Poor sleep reduces the muscles' ability to recover

 Vitamin D deficiency: Approximately one-third of MPS patients have low vitamin D levels

 Trauma: Among whiplash patients, 55-65% have trigger points in the levator scapulae

Hvem rammes?: Fettpute-atrofi rammer primært personer over 60 år , men kan oppstå tidligere ved spesifikke risikofaktorer. Tilstanden er en vanlig, men ofte oversett årsak til kroniske forfotssmerter.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer: Det er en naturlig prosess som akselererer etter 50-60 år. Kollagen og elastiske fibre brytes ned, fettkapselen mister volum, og du mister den naturlige dempingen under forfoten.

Symptomer: Det typiske bildet er gradvis utviklende forfotssmerter over måneder til år
Diagnostikk: Diagnosen stilles primært klinisk ved å kjenne etter tap av polstring under metatarsalhodene.

Behandling: Fettputene vokser ikke tilbake av seg selv. Men symptomene kan håndteres godt med riktige tiltak - målet er å erstatte den tapte dempingen med ytre støtdemping.

Prognose: Fettpute-atrofi er en kronisk tilstand som ikke reverseres . Men med riktig avlastning, gode sko og eventuelt innleggssåler opplever mange god smertelindring og kan fortsette å være aktive.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Hallux Rigidus (Stiv Storta).

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Kan hallux rigidus bli bedre uten operasjon?

 Ja, mange opplever betydelig bedring med konservativ behandling, spesielt i tidlige stadier (grad 1-2). Mobilisering, riktig fottoy, innlegg og Øvelser kan redusere smerter og bedre funksjon vesentlig. Tilstanden blir ikke "kurert", men symptomene kan kontrolleres godt.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på hallux rigidus og hallux valgus?

 Hallux rigidus er artrose med stivhet i stortåens grunnledd - tøen forblir vanligvis rett, men blir stiv. Hallux valgus (kjulebein) er en feilstilling der stortåen bøyes mot de andre tårne og gir en kul på innsiden av foten. Begge kan gi smerter, men Årsakene og behandlingen er ulik.

 

 
 Hvilke sko er best ved hallux rigidus?

 Velg sko med stiv såle (rocker-sole), romslig tøboks og lav hæl. Skoene bør ikke bøyes mye ved stortåen. Unngå høyhelte sko og fleksible såler som tvinger leddet til å bøye seg. Spesialinnlegg (Morton's extension) kan våre nyttig.

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det for hallux rigidus blir verre?

 Progresjonen varierer sterkt fra person til person. Noen forblir stabile i mange Ør, mens andre opplever gradvis forverring over måneder til Ør. Tidlig behandling, aktivitetstilpasning og riktig fottoy kan bremse utviklingen betydelig.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med hallux rigidus?

 Ja, men velg aktiviteter som ikke belaster stortaens grunnledd for mye. Sykling og svomming er ofte gode alternativer. Unngå aktiviteter som krever kraftig avspark fra stortaen (loping...

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Osteoporose og kompresjonsfrakturer i ryggen.

Symptomer

 

 Her kommer en overraskende opplysning: 65-75 % av alle vertebrale frakturer gir ingen eller minimale symptomer (AAFP, 2016). Mange oppdages tilfeldig på røntgen eller MR tatt av andre Årsaker.

 Når symptomer oppstår, ser jeg ofte:

 
 Plutselig, intens smerte midt i ryggen eller i overgangen bryst-/korsrygg - lignende brystryggsmerter

 Smerten forverres ved stillingsendring, hosting eller løfting

 Bedring i hvile og liggende stilling

 Gradvis høydetap over tid

 Økende krumning av Øvre rygg (kyfose) - se krum rygg

 

 
 Det typiske scenarioet

 En eldre person, ofte kvinne, opplever plutselig kraftig ryggsmerte etter å ha bøyd seg ned eller løftet noe lett. Det var intet tydelig fall eller traume.

 

 Nyttige kliniske tegn

 To kliniske tegn har vist seg nyttige:

 
 Knyttneve-perkusjonstesten (å banke lett på virvelen) har sensitivitet på 87,5 % og spesifisitet på 90 %.

 "Supine sign" - at pasienten ikke klarer å ligge flatt med kun en pute på grunn av smerte - har sensitivitet 81 % og spesifisitet 93 % (PMC, 2011).
Generer observasjon for gravid pasient
Gravid habitus, uke 28. Økt lumballordose. Breddeøkt bekken-gange. Ingen ødemer i underekstremiteter. Generelt godt allmenntilstand.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Triggerfinger: Komplett guide.

Behandling

 

 
 Prognose er god

 
 52% av milde tilfeller går over spontant

 63-80% blir bra med kortison

 Kirurgi har >90% suksessrate for resten

 
 

 Behandlingstrappen

 
 1. Avlastning og skinne

 Fingerortose som holder fingeren strakt om natten. Ofte nok for milde tilfeller.

 

 
 2. Kortison (Effektivt)

 Kortisoninjeksjon i seneskjeden har 63-80% suksessrate. Kan gjentas 1-2 ganger.

 

 
 3. Kirurgi

 A1-pulley release - en enkel dagkirurgisk prosedyre med >90% suksess.

 

 
 Sjokkbolgebehandling (ESWT)

 En systematisk oversikt fra Brancaccio et al. (2024) konkluderer at ESWT ikke har bevist effekt for triggerfinger. Ikke anbefalt som behandling.

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Hallux Rigidus.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Årsaken til hallux rigidus er ofte multifaktoriell. I mange tilfeller finner man ingen klar utløsende årsak.

 Tidligere skade

 Skade mot stortaen ("turf toe") eller gjentatte mikrotaumer øker risikoen betydelig. Se også ankelforstuinger 

 Genetikk

 Sterk familiør opphopning tyder på arvelig komponent

 Fotstruktur

 Lang storta, flat fot eller høy fotbue kan disponere

 Overbelastning

 Yrker med mye kneling, hoking eller tunge løft

 Inflammatorisk sykdom

 Revmatoid artritt og gikt kan bidra til utvikling

Describe Limit Pain Medication in the context of Headache on Top of the Head.

Limit Pain Medication

 Avoid daily use of paracetamol or NSAIDs to prevent medication overuse headache.

 

 Treatment Course

 Dose-response studies for cervicogenic headache found that 8-10 treatments over 6 weeks was effective. For most patients, you can expect immediate relief after the first treatment, significant improvement after 4-8 weeks, and full effect after 6-8 weeks of treatment and exercises.

 

 
 
 
 6
 Prognosis

 

 Most people with headache on top of the head have a good prognosis. Tension headache and neck-related causes often respond well to treatment.

 Short-term

 Good probability of improvement with treatment - one study found that 72% of patients with cervicogenic headache maintained at least 50% reduction in headache frequency after 12 months.

 Relapses are Common

 Headache tends to return, especially with persistent risk factors like stress and static work. This does not mean treatment has failed - it means prevention and self-management are important.

 Long-term

 Evidence suggests that different treatments often give similar results over time. The most important factor for sustained improvement appears to be regular exercises and lifestyle changes.

 

 
 
 
 7
 Frequently Asked Questions

Describe diagnosis for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over Your Life.

Diagnosis

 Barany Society/IHS Diagnostic Criteria
 For the diagnosis "Definite Vestibular Migraine" the following must be met
 At least 5 episodes with vestibular symptoms of moderate to severe intensity

 Duration from 5 minutes to 72 hours

 Current or past history of migraine (with or without aura)

 At least 50% of attacks must have at least one migraine feature: headache, light/sound sensitivity, or visual aura

 Symptoms cannot be better explained by another diagnosis

 Differential Diagnosis
 Condition 
 Duration 
 Distinctive Features 

 Vestibular Migraine 
 Minutes to hours 
 Migraine features, gradual onset 

 BPPV (Crystal Disease) 
 Seconds 
 Sudden onset, specific head position 

 Meniere's Disease 
 Hours 
 Progressive hearing loss, unilateral fullness 

 Vestibular Neuritis 
 Days 
 Single episode, gradual improvement 

 Red Flags - See a Doctor or Emergency Room for
 Sudden, intense headache ("the worst headache of my life")

 Headache with fever and neck stiffness

 Unilateral hearing loss or tinnitus

 Double vision or vision loss

 Weakness or numbness in face, arm or leg

 Speech or language difficulties

 Fainting in connection with dizziness

Describe Solutions and Prevention for Text Neck and Jaw Pain: How Mobile Use Affects the Jaw.

Solutions and Prevention

 

 
 1. Change Mobile Habits

 
 Hold your phone higher: Raise it to eye level

 Limit time: Set limits on screen time

 Take breaks: 20-20-20 rule (every 20 min, look at something 20 m away for 20 sec)

 Alternate: Switch between holding the phone with right and left hand

 
 

 
 2. Optimize Your Workstation

 
 Screen height: Top edge at eye level

 Screen distance: One arm's length

 Chair: Back support and correct height

 Standing desk: Variation is good

 
 

 3. Exercises

 
 Chin Tuck

 
 Sit or stand straight

 Pull your chin straight back (like a "double chin")

 Hold for 5 seconds

 Repeat 10 times, several times daily

 
 

 
 Neck Stretch

 
 Gently tilt your head to the side (ear toward shoulder)

 Hold 20-30 seconds

 Repeat on the opposite side

 
 

 
 Chest Muscle Stretch

 
 Stand in a doorway with forearms against the frame

 Take a step forward

 Feel the stretch in your chest

 Hold 30 seconds

 
 

 
 Shoulder Blade Retraction

 
 Pull your shoulder blades together and down

 Hold 5 seconds

 Repeat 10 times

Hva er en stressfraktur?

 

 Bein er levende vev som stadig brytes ned og bygges opp. Når belastningen er større enn beinets kapasitet til å reparere seg, oppstar først en "stressreaksjon" - en forløper til fraktur. Mobiliseringsøvelser

 Start alltid med mobilisering for å varme opp leddene og gjenopprette bevegelighet. Disse øvelsene er skånsomme nok til å gjøres selv på dårlige dager.

 Forsiktig nakkerotasjon

 Sitt oppreist med avslappede skuldre

 Snu hodet sakte mot høyre — til et komfortabelt endepunkt

 Hold i 3-5 sekunder

 Tilbake til midten, gjenta til venstre

 Dosering: 10 repetisjoner til hver side

 Tips: Beveg deg bare innenfor smertefritt utslag. Rekkevidden øker naturlig etter noen repetisjoner.

 Sidebøy med gravitasjonsassist

 Vipp øret mot skulderen — la tyngdekraften gjøre jobben

 Ikke løft skulderen — hold den avslappet

 Hold i 5 sekunder, kjenn et lett strekk

 Tilbake, gjenta til motsatt side

 Dosering: 10 repetisjoner til hver side

 Fleksjon-ekstensjon (kontrollert nikking)

 Bøy hodet forsiktig fremover, haken mot brystet

 Hold 2-3 sekunder

 Bøy hodet forsiktig bakover, se opp i taket

 Hold 2-3 sekunder

 Dosering: 10 repetisjoner

 OBS: Stopp ektensjonen dersom du opplever svimmelhet.

Describe The Jaw and Posture Are Connected for Breathing, Stress and Back.

The Jaw and Posture Are Connected

 

 What Does the Research Show?

 Numbers have circulated that "49% of people with poor posture have jaw problems." I found no scientific
 support for this after extensive searching.

 What is actually documented (Xiao et al., 2023) is a weak but statistically significant
 correlation between forward head posture and temporomandibular disorders (TMD). The correlation
 is r=0.16-0.23 - thus much weaker than the viral claims.

 More interesting is that 88.5% of TMD patients have at least one postural deviation (Di
 Francesco et al., 2023). Forward head posture is 2.4 times more common in people with muscular TMD than in
 controls (Cortese et al., 2017).

 
 What Does This Mean in Practice?

 The connection is likely bidirectional: Poor posture can contribute to jaw tension, and jaw tension can
 affect neck and head posture. For many patients, it makes sense to treat both simultaneously.

Describe causes and risk factors for Whiplash.

Causes and risk factors

 Most common causes

 Car accidents (whiplash)

 The classic cause. During rear-end collision, the neck is exposed to rapid acceleration-deceleration
 that can damage soft tissues.

 Sports injuries

 Contact sports such as football, rugby, and martial arts increase risk through direct impacts or
 falls.

 Falls and accidents

 Falls from height or sudden movements can cause soft tissue injuries.

 Risk factors for prolonged symptoms

 Research has identified several factors that increase the risk of chronic symptoms (Walton et al.,
 2013)
 High pain intensity from the start (above 5.5/10)

 High functional disability from the start

 Catastrophizing (excessive worry about symptoms)

 Fear of movement

 Previous neck problems

 Post-traumatic stress symptoms

 Interesting finding

 Research shows that the collision itself (direction, speed, headrest type) does not significantly
 affect prognosis. Imaging findings also do not predict prognosis - psychosocial factors matter far
 more.

Skriv henvisning til MR for cervikal radikulopati.

Til: Radiologisk avdeling
Fra: [Klinikknavn], kiropraktor
Dato: [dato]

Pasient: [Navn], [alder] år
Henvisningsgrunn: Cervikal radikulopati C6 høyre

Anamnese: 6 ukers sykehistorie med nakkesmerter og utstråling til høyre arm i C6-distribusjon (lateral underarm, tommel). VAS 6/10. Forverres ved cervikal ekstensjon og høyre rotasjon. Parestesier i tommel intermitterende.

Kliniske funn: Positiv Spurlings test høyre med utstråling til C6-dermatom. Svekket bicepsrefleks høyre (1+ vs 2+ venstre). Kraft: Biceps 4+/5 høyre. Sensibilitet: Lett nedsatt berøringssans laterale underarm og tommel høyre.

Konservativ behandling med manuell terapi og øvelser i 4 uker uten tilfredsstillende bedring.

Ønske: MR cervikalt for å vurdere diskpatologi og foraminal stenose C5-C6.

Hastegrad: Innen 2 uker (progredierende nevrologisk utfall).

Explain Trigger Points in Arm and Forearm to a patient.

You may have received a diagnosis of tennis elbow or carpal tunnel syndrome , but treatment isn't working. The pain
 moves around, comes and goes, and you feel tender knots in the muscles when you press. Could the cause
 be trigger points?

 Trigger points are one of the most overlooked causes of arm pain. Data from pain clinics shows that
 85-95% of patients with chronic pain have trigger points as a primary or contributing
 cause.

 Let's look at what trigger points are, how they develop, and why they're so often misdiagnosed as other
 conditions.

Describe Exercise 2: Toe Spreading for Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Exercise 2: Toe Spreading

 

 After years in narrow shoes, many have lost the ability to actively spread their toes. Toe spreading reactivates the abductor muscles and improves forefoot stability.

 
 How to Perform Toe Spreading

 
 Starting position: Sit or stand with your foot flat on the floor

 Movement: Spread the toes as far apart as possible

 Focus: Especially try to spread the big toe away from the others

 Hold: 5-10 seconds

 Repetitions: 10-15 reps

 Sets: 2-3 sets per foot

 
 

 
 Tip: Use Toe Spacers

 If you struggle to spread your toes, toe spacers can help. Use them passively while sitting or sleeping to gradually regain toe mobility. Start with 15-30 minutes and increase gradually.

Describe where does it hurt? find your pain type for Hip Pain?.

Where Does It Hurt? Find Your Pain Type

 Instead of listing diagnoses, I'll start with what you actually notice: where is the pain located? This often gives the best clue to what's wrong.

 1 
 Pain on the OUTSIDE of the hip

 Condition 
 Key Symptoms 
 Tests & Differentiation 

 GTPS (Gluteal Tendinopathy) 
 Very Common 

 Pain when lying on side at night.

 Pain with stairs, uphill walking.

 Tender over the bony prominence (trochanter).

 Single-leg stance test: Standing on one leg for 30 seconds reproduces the familiar pain.

 Read more about GTPS ? 

 Referred Back Pain 
 Common 

 Pain radiates from lower back.

 Often goes past the knee .

 Variable pain pattern (good/bad days).

 Slump test: Stretching the nerve pathway reproduces the pain.

 Pain often triggered by bending the back (not the hip).

 Trochanteric Bursitis 
 Rare ( 

 Acute swelling, redness and warmth.

 Pain with ANY movement of the leg.

 Most "bursitis" diagnoses are actually tendon injuries (GTPS). True bursitis shows signs of inflammation.

 Who is affected? GTPS occurs in 15% of women and 6-8% of men between 50-79 years. Women are affected over 3 times as often.

 Prognosis: Most improve significantly with proper exercise. See treatment results .

 2 
 Pain in the GROIN (front of hip)

 Condition 
 Key Symptoms 
 Tests & Differentiation 

 Hip Osteoarthritis 
 Common (50+) 

 Morning stiffness.

 Deep, aching pain in groin/front of thigh.

 Difficulty putting on socks.

 Reduced mobility: Loss of internal rotation.

 X-ray shows joint space narrowing.

 Read about hip OA ? 

 FAI (Impingement) 
 Young/active 

 Sharp pinching pain with deep squats/flexion.

 Clicking or locking.

 "C-sign" (gripping hip with hand).

 FADIR test: Deep flexion + internal rotation causes sharp pain.

 37% of pain-free people have FAI on MRI.

 Read about FAI ? 

 Labral Tear 
 Young/active 

 Clicking, locking.

 Feeling that hip "pops out".

 Sharp pain with twisting.

Assess red flags: 45-year-old female with left-sided chest pain worse with deep inspiration. No dyspnea. SpO2 98%. Normal pulse 72/min. Reproducible pain with palpation of sternocostal joints. No calf pain.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why pleuritic chest pain is NOT pulmonary embolism here:
- Pain is REPRODUCIBLE with palpation (mechanical cause)
- Normal SpO2 (98%) — PE typically causes SpO2 <95%
- Normal pulse (PE causes tachycardia >100)
- No dyspnea (PE almost always causes dyspnea)
- No calf pain/swelling (PE often starts with DVT)
- No risk factors (immobilization, OCP, recent surgery)

Clinical picture: Costochondritis/sternocostal dysfunction.

Safe to treat with sternocostal joint mobilization, stretching, cryotherapy.

Symptoms

 

 
 Typical Symptoms

 Direct pressure on the nerve

 Constant numbness (not just intermittent)

 Visible muscle wasting between fingers

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

3 Common Causes of Thoracic Back Pain

 Most thoracic back pain is caused by mechanical issues that can be effectively treated by a chiropractor:

 
 Rib Joint Dysfunction (Costovertebral Dysfunction)

 The most common cause of thoracic back pain. Occurs when the joints between the ribs and vertebrae become stiff or "locked."

 
 Sharp pain with breathing and movement

 Point tenderness at the rib attachment

 Often triggered by twisting or lifting

 Responds very well to chiropractic treatment

 
 

 
 Costochondritis

 Inflammation in the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone. Causes pain at the front of the chest but often related to thoracic dysfunction.

 
 Tender to touch at the breastbone

 Can mimic heart pain

 Worse with coughing and deep breathing

 Often self-limiting, but treatment helps

 
 

 
 Thoracic Facet Joint Dysfunction

 Stiffness or irritation in the small joints between the vertebrae in the thoracic spine.

 
 Stiff and aching pain between the shoulder blades

 Worse with extension (bending backward)

 Often related to poor posture

 Common in office workers

 
 

 
 Myofascial Trigger Points

 Painful knots in the muscles, especially in the rhomboids, trapezius, and erector spinae.

 
 Often refer pain to other areas

 Can cause headaches and neck pain

 Often related to stress and overload

 Treated effectively with soft tissue treatment

 
 

 
 Poor Posture and Ergonomics

 Prolonged poor loading from office work, mobile phone use, or on...

Beskriv Den store forvekslingen for Bihulehodepine eller migrene?.

Den store forvekslingen

 

 
 
 88%
 har migrene, ikke bihulebetennelse
 

 
 8 Ør
 gjennomsnittlig feildiagnose
 

 
 12%
 unødvendig operert
 

 

 Tilsvarende funn kom i SAMS-studien fra 2007, hvor kun 3% av deltakerne faktisk hadde hodepine fra bihulebetennelse. Resten hadde migrene eller andre hodepinetyper.

 
 Hvorfor forveksles de?

 Trigeminusnerven forsyner både hjernehinnene (der migrene oppstår) og bihulene. Når migrene aktiverer denne nerven, utløses en refleks som gir tett nese, rennende Øyne og trykk i ansiktet - symptomer vi forbinder med forkjølelse eller bihulebetennelse.

 Studier viser at 40-74% av migrenepasienter opplever minst ett slikt "bihulelignende" symptom under anfall.

 

 
 Den kritiske forskjellen

 Migrene gir klar væske fra nesen (fra nerveaktivering)

 Bakteriell bihulebetennelse gir gulgrénn, tykk slim (fra infeksjon)

Describe Neck problems after birth and during breastfeeding for Neck Pain During Pregnancy - Causes and Safe Treatment.

Neck problems after birth and during breastfeeding

 

 Neck problems don't necessarily disappear after birth - in fact, up to 72% of breastfeeding women report musculoskeletal complaints. "Nursing neck" describes neck pain that occurs from repeated forward-bent position during breastfeeding.

 
 Tips for breastfeeding mothers

 
 Bring the baby to the breast, not the breast to the baby

 Vary breastfeeding positions - try side-lying feeding

 Support neck and back with good chair and pillows

 Take breaks and do stretching exercises between feeding sessions

Differential diagnoses for Numbness in Fingers: Is It the Neck or the Hand??

Carpal tunnel syndrome - the wrist

 The carpal tunnel is a narrow passage in the wrist where the median nerve passes through. When space becomes too tight, typically due to swelling in tendons or surrounding tissue, the nerve doesn't have enough room.

 Affects 1-5% of the population. Women are affected 3-4 times more often than men, most commonly between ages 40-60.

Cervical radiculopathy - the neck

 With cervical radiculopathy, a nerve root in the neck is pinched or irritated, usually due to degenerative changes (70-75%) or disc herniation (20-25%).

Skriv subjektiv del av SOAP-notat for en pasient med Scheuermanns sykdom.

Scheuermanns sykdom er en vekstforstyrrelse i ryggsøylen som oppstar i puberteten. Under vekstspurten utvikler flere ryggvirvler seg ujevnt - den fremre delen vokser saktere enn den bakre. Resultatet er kileformede virvler som skaper en permanent, Økt krumning i brystryggen.

 Tilstanden ble først beskrevet av den danske ortoped Holger Werfel Scheuermann i 1920. Hans danske kollega Kaj Sorensen etablerte de diagnostiske kriteriene i 1964, som fortsatt brukes internasjonalt i dag.

Patient asks: "What is the difference between meralgia paresthetica and sciatica?"

Meralgia paresthetica affects the front/outer thigh and only causes sensory symptoms (numbness, tingling, burning). Sciatica affects the back of the leg, can go all the way to the foot, and can cause both pain and weakness. They are two completely different nerves.

Describe Types of Dizziness After Concussion for Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

Types of Dizziness After Concussion

 

 
 Crystal Dizziness (BPPV) - 10-57%

 Here, small calcium crystals have loosened from their normal position in the balance organ and ended up in the semicircular canals. Post-traumatic BPPV often behaves differently than regular BPPV - it more often affects multiple canals simultaneously and can be more resistant to treatment.

 

 
 Vestibulo-ocular Dysfunction - Over 50%

 Problems with the reflex that keeps your gaze stable when the head moves. Symptoms are often blurred vision during head movements, difficulty reading, and dizziness in visually demanding environments.

 

 
 Neck-Related Dizziness - 20-58%

 Occurs in people with whiplash and often appears together with vestibular complaints. The neck contains many sensitive receptors that give the brain information about head position.

Describe Strategies to Break the Cycle for Stress and Jaw Pain: How Stress Settles in the Jaw.

Strategies to Break the Cycle

 

 
 1. Awareness - The Most Important First Step

 You can't change something you're not aware of:

 
 Set reminders: Use your phone or post-it notes to remind yourself to check the jaw

 Body scanning: Several times daily - is the jaw relaxed?

 Trigger situations: Notice when you clench (screen work, driving, stressful conversations)

 
 

 
 2. Rest Position for the Jaw

 Teach your jaw a new default setting:

 
 "N technique": Say the letter "N" and hold the jaw in that position

 Mantra: "Lips together, teeth apart"

 Tongue: Rest against the palate, just behind the front teeth

 
 

 
 3. Breathing Techniques

 Breathing and jaw are closely connected:

 
 4-7-8 breathing: In for 4, hold for 7, out for 8

 Diaphragmatic breathing: Breathe deeply into the belly

 Breathe through the nose: Calmer than mouth breathing

 
 

 
 4. Progressive Muscle Relaxation

 
 Press teeth hard together for 5 seconds

 Release completely and feel the contrast

 Let the jaw hang heavy for 10 seconds

 Repeat 3-5 times

 
 By tensing first, you learn to feel the difference between tense and relaxed.

 

 
 5. General Stress Management

 
 Regular physical activity: Releases tension from the body

 Sleep hygiene: Stress and poor sleep reinforce each other

 Breaks: Short breaks throughout the workday

 Boundary setting: Say no to overload

 Mindfulness/meditation: Documented effect on stress response

Describe causes and risk factors for Golfer's Elbow: Everything You Need to Know.

Causes and risk factors

 Over 90% of golfer's elbow cases are caused by work-related factors - not golf (Descatha et al., 2003). The most
 common causes are
 Repetitive manual work Most common 

 Manual labor like carpentry, plumbing, painting. Repetitive gripping and twisting movements over time.

 Office work

 Prolonged mouse and keyboard use, especially with poor ergonomics. Often combined with tennis elbow.
 See our article on mouse arm .

 Throwing sports

 Baseball, handball, javelin throwing. Repetitive throwing motions strain the inside of the elbow.

 Golf (5-10% of cases)

 Actually only a small proportion. Most common in beginners with incorrect technique.

 Important risk factors

 Repetitive gripping movements: Same movement thousands of times

 Heavy lifting with bent wrist: Increases strain on the inside

 Vibration: Use of vibrating tools (drill, grinder)

 Age 40-60 years: Natural aging of tendon tissue

 Smokers: Poorer blood supply to tendons

Describe symptoms for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 Symptoms of calcific tendinitis vary significantly depending on which phase the condition is in
 Typical symptoms

 Pain: Localized to the outside of the shoulder/upper arm. May radiate down to the
 elbow.

 Night pain: Common, especially when lying on the affected side. Read more about sleep and shoulder pain 

 Restricted movement: Difficulty lifting the arm to the side and overhead

 Sudden worsening: Acute, intense pain during transition to the resorptive phase

 Acute presentation (resorptive phase)

 Sudden onset of intense pain, often at night. The shoulder may be very tender to touch, and the
 patient often holds the arm completely still to avoid pain. The condition can resemble septic
 arthritis or gout.

 Chronic presentation (resting/formation phase)

 Gradually increasing pain over time. The pain worsens with activity, especially movements above
 shoulder height. May resemble impingement syndrome.

 Clinical tests

 On examination, we often find
 Painful arc during abduction (60-120 degrees)

 Positive Neer's and/or Hawkins test

 Point tenderness over the supraspinatus attachment

 In acute phase: Heat, swelling, marked tenderness

Provide a structured clinical overview of Dizziness.

The Body's Balance System: To understand dizziness, you must first look at our amazing balance system. Balance is not one single thing, but a continuous collaboration between three critical systems that constantly communicate with the brain.

Common Causes of Dizziness: BPPV is the most common cause of dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all cases. The condition occurs when small calcium crystals dislodge from their normal place in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

Diagnosis - What Can You Expect?: A thorough examination always starts with listening to your history. I map when symptoms occur, what triggers them, how long they last, and if there are other accompanying symptoms.

Treatment Options: Repositioning maneuvers (Epley/Semont) have an 80-90% success rate . Many experience significant improvement after 1-3 treatments.

Frequently Asked Questions: BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) is the most common cause and accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness cases. It has a success rate of 80-90% with the Epley maneuver.

Ready to Get Help?: . I offer thorough assessment with VNG and TRV chair to find the cause and provide the right treatment.

Årsaker til svimmelhet og kvalme: Benign paroksysmal posisjonsvertigo (BPPV), ofte kalt krystallsyke, er den vanligste årsaken til svimmelhet når du søker hjelp hos spesialist. Ifølge von Brevern (2007) utgjør BPPV 17-42% av konsultasjonene ved svimmelhetsklinikker. Livstidsprevalensen i befolkningen er 2,4%.

Behandling: Epley-manøveren er gullstandarden. Cochrane-gjennomgangen viser at 74% oppnår symptomfrihet - 6,5 ganger bedre enn kontrollgrupper. En systematisk oversikt fra 2022 viser NNT på 3, altså at hver tredje pasient som behandles blir symptomfri sammenlignet med ingen behandling.

Ofte stilte spørsmål: Det avhenger av årsaken. Ved BPPV varer kvalmen typisk sekunder til minutter etter hodebevegelse. Ved vestibularisnevritt kan kvalmen være vedvarende i dager. Ved migrene kan den vare i timer.

Er du svimmel og kvalm?: . Jeg tilbyr grundig utredning med VNG og TRV-stol for å finne årsaken og gi riktig behandling.

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral hand numbness is NOT myelopathy:

- Myelopathy causes numbness that does NOT improve with shaking
- Positive bilateral Phalen confirms peripheral compression (median nerve)

- Bilateral CTS is common (up to 50% of cases)

Clinical picture: Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome.

Patient asks: "What is the difference between tendinopathy and a tear?"

What are trigger points?

 

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle fibers - often described as "knots" or "tightness."
 When you press on a trigger point, it causes characteristic pain, and often also referred
 pain - pain that radiates to other areas.

 There are two main types:

 
 Active trigger points Cause symptoms

 Cause spontaneous pain and referred pain. Can disturb sleep and affect daily function.

 

 
 Latent trigger points

 Only tender when pressed. Can limit mobility and weaken the muscle, but don't cause spontaneous pain.

Cauda Equina Syndrome - Emergency Situation

 Cauda equina syndrome (CES) occurs when the nerve bundle at the bottom of the spinal cord becomes
 compressed, usually by a large disc herniation . The condition affects
 approximately 1.6 per 100,000 per year - rare, but very serious.

 1.6

 Symptoms to Watch For

 Cauda Equina Symptoms

Describe symptoms and signs of Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 

 Tension headache has characteristic features that distinguish it from other headache types. According to ICHD-3 criteria (International Headache Society 2018), at least two of the following must be present:

 
 Bilateral location - the pain sits on both sides of the head, often in the back of the head or forehead

 Pressing or tightening quality - not pulsating

 Mild to moderate intensity - you can usually continue with daily activities

 Not worsened by physical activity - walking stairs or light movement does not make it worse

 

 
 Important difference from migraine

 With tension headache, you typically do not experience nausea or vomiting. Light or sound sensitivity may occur, but never both at the same time.

 

 Tension Headache vs. Migraine

 Headache in the temple or top of the head can occur in both conditions, but the character is different.

Evidence-based treatment

 

 AAOS (American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons) updated their guidelines in 2024. Here's what the
 research shows:

 
 First choice: Night splint

 
 50-70% experience improvement with nightly use of wrist splint

 Keeps the wrist in neutral position during sleep

 Significantly reduces night symptoms

 Recommended as first-line treatment (AAOS 2024)

 
 

 
 Manual therapy matches surgery short-term

 An important study (Fernandez-de-las-Penas et al.) showed that manual treatment gave equally
 good results as surgery at 1 and 3 month follow-up. This included:

 
 Nerve gliding exercises

 Myofascial release of forearm and hand

 Mobilization of wrist bones

 
 

 Treatment plan at Chiropractor Mads Finstad

 
 1. Night splint (first choice)

 Guidance on proper use of wrist splint. Must be used every night for at least 3-4 weeks to evaluate
 effect.

 

 
 2. Nerve gliding exercises

 Structured exercises that mobilize the median nerve through its path, to reduce adhesions and improve
 nerve mobility.

 

 
 3. Manual treatment

 Soft tissue treatment of forearm, mobilization of wrist bones, and nerve gliding techniques.

 

 
 4. Ergonomic guidance

 Assessment of workstation, mouse use and keyboard height. Small changes can make a big difference.

 

 When is surgery considered?

 
 No effect from conservative treatment after 3-6 months

 Severe symptoms with constant numbness

 Visible muscle wasting (thenar atrophy)

 Significantly reduced ...

Describe symptoms of l4-l5 herniation for L4.

Symptoms of L4-L5 herniation

 L5 nerve root (most common)

 With the common paracentral herniation type, the L5 nerve root is compressed. This produces a characteristic symptom pattern
 Typical symptoms
 Pain: Radiates from the buttock along the outer thigh, down the lateral calf to the top of the foot and big toe (sciatica). The pain is often described as sharp, burning, or electric.

 Sensory changes: Reduced sensation or numbness between the big toe and second toe is a relatively specific finding (75% specificity). Many also experience numbness on the top of the foot and lateral calf.

 Muscle weakness: Can affect hip abduction, dorsiflexion of the foot, and big toe extension. Many notice this as difficulty walking on heels.

 Reflex: There is no reliable reflex for the L5 nerve root, which can make diagnosis more challenging.

 L4 nerve root (with far lateral herniation)

 With far lateral herniation, the L4 nerve root can be compressed. This causes pain on the front of the thigh and medial calf, weakness in knee extension, and reduced or absent knee reflex.

Describe most common headache types for Headaches and Migraines.

1 Most Common Headache Types

 Tension Headache

 78% experience it in their lifetime - Tension headache is by far the most common headache type. For most, it comes and goes, perhaps after a long day at the screen. But for some, it becomes chronic.

 Feeling: Pressing or tight pain – like a tight band around the head

 Intensity: Mild to moderate

 Location: Both sides of the head

 Often worse throughout the day

 Does NOT worsen with normal physical activity

 Common causes: Muscle tension in neck/shoulders/jaw, poor posture, stress, sleep deprivation, teeth grinding

 Migraine

 About 15% of women, 6-7% of men - Migraine is a neurological condition. Women are affected more often.

 Feeling: Intense, throbbing or pulsating pain

 Often on one side of the head

 Nausea and/or vomiting

 Extreme sensitivity to light and sound

 Physical activity worsens the pain

 Duration: 4–72 hours

 Migraine with aura: 20-30% experience visual disturbances like flashing lights or zigzag patterns before the headache.

 Cervicogenic Headache (Neck Headache)

 15-20% of chronic headaches - Cervicogenic headache is caused by dysfunction in cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) or soft tissue in the neck. This is the headache type that often responds well to chiropractic treatment. 

 Pain that starts in the neck and radiates upward toward forehead, temple or around the eye

 Typically one-sided – rarely changes sides

 Gets worse with certain neck movements or positions

 Often accompanied by neck stiffness

 Responds poorly to regular painkillers

 Cluster Headache

 0.1% of the population - Rare but extremely painful. Intense attacks lasting 15 minutes to 3 hours, often several times daily in "clusters" over weeks. Requires specialized treatment.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Triggerpunkter og Myofascielt Smertesyndrom i Nakken.

Behandling

 

 
 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En nettverks-metaanalyse fra 2024 viser at manuell behandling gir korttidsbedring av smerte, trykkomfintlighet og funksjon.

 
 Ischemisk kompresjon: Vedvarende trykk på triggerpunktet gir signifikant bedring i trykksmerteterskel

 Dry needling: Tynne nåler settes direkte i triggerpunktet. Like effektivt som manuell triggerpunktbehandling på kort og mellomlang sikt

 Myofascielle teknikker og mobilisering: Bløtvevsbehandling av muskler og fascia

 Leddmobilisering/manipulasjon: Ved samtidig leddysfunksjon i nakke eller brystrygg

 
 

 
 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 En systematisk oversikt viser at kombinert tøying og styrketrening gir best effekt på myofascielle smerter:

 
 Tøying: Hold i 30 sekunder - dette er optimal varighet ifølge forskning. Tøy trapezius, levator scapulae og skalener daglig

 Styrketrening: Øvelser for dyp nakkemuskulatur og skulderbladsstabilisatorer

 Ergonomi: Skjerm i øyehøyde, underarmer støttet, regelmessige pauser. Unngå fremskutt hodestilling

 Selvmassasje: Bruk en tennisball eller lacrosseball mot veggen for forsiktig trykk på ømme punkter. 30-60 sekunder per punkt

 Stressmestring: Kronisk stress vedlikeholder muskelspenninger. Vurder pusteteknikker eller mindfulness

 
 

 
 Korttidseffektene av behandling er godt dokumentert. For varig effekt er det viktig å kombinere behandling med egentrening og å adressere underliggende faktorer som stress, ergonomi og søvn.

Explain prognosis for Vestibular Neuritis.

Prognosis

 Vestibular neuritis is a self-limiting condition with generally good prognosis
 2-3 weeks 
 significant improvement 

 3-6 mo 
 full compensation 

 50-70% 
 full recovery 

 Most experience significant improvement within 2-3 weeks

 Full compensation (can run, turn quickly without problems) can take 3-6 months

 Approximately 50-70% achieve full or near-full recovery

 30-50% develop persistent, milder dizziness

 Interesting Finding

 Long-term prognosis does not depend on how much nerve function is restored. Even if caloric testing still shows significant asymmetry, patients can become completely symptom-free because the brain compensates effectively.

 Factors Predicting Poorer Recovery
 High degree of anxiety at disease onset

 Strong visual dependency (relying too much on vision for balance)

 Avoidance behavior (lying still for too long)

 Prolonged use of vestibular suppressants

 In some cases, persistent symptoms can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness) , especially with strong anxiety or avoidance behavior. Patients with vestibular migraine may also have increased risk for poorer outcomes.

 Risk of Recurrence

 Recurrence in the same ear is rare - the nerve is often permanently damaged

 Risk of getting it in the other ear is approximately 2-4% over a lifetime

Hva er osteoporose og kompresjonsfrakturer?

 

 Norge ligger i verdenstoppen for hoftefrakturer, og benmassen i den norske befolkningen ser ut til å våre blant de laveste i Europå (NOREPOS, 2014). Kombinert med utbredt vitamin D-mangel - rundt 40 % av voksne nordmenn har for lave nivåer - skaper dette et sårbart utgangspunkt for mange eldre (HUNT-studien, 2014).

 
 Livstidsrisiko

 Livstidsrisikoen for vertebral fraktur ved 50-Ørsalder er 16-18 % for kvinner og 5-11 % for menn. Ved 80 Ør har opptil 40 % hatt minst en kompresjonsfraktur (NCBI StatPearls, 2024).

Describe Risk factors in the context of Shoulder Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

Secondary osteoarthritis

 

 Result of another condition or injury:

 
 Previous shoulder fracture or dislocation

 Rotator cuff tear (cuff tear arthropathy)

 Rheumatoid arthritis

 Avascular necrosis

 Joint infection

 
 

 Risk factors

 
 Age over 60 years

 Previous shoulder injury or surgery

 Long-standing rotator cuff tear

 Repeated dislocations

 Heavy physical work over time

 Rheumatoid arthritis or other inflammatory conditions

 
 

 
 
 3
 Symptoms

 

 Symptoms of shoulder osteoarthritis usually develop gradually:

 Typical symptoms

 
 Pain: Deep, aching pain in the shoulder. Often worse with activity.

 Stiffness: Reduced mobility, especially rotation

 Crepitation: Creaking or grating during movement

 Night pain: Can wake you up or make it difficult to find a sleeping position. Read
 more about sleep and shoulder pain

 Activity-related pain: Worsens with use, improves with rest

 

 
 Movements that often provoke symptoms

 
 Putting on a jacket or sweater

 Reaching behind the back (bra clasp, wallet)

 Lifting the arm out to the side

 Rotational movements

 
 

 Difference from frozen shoulder

 
 Shoulder osteoarthritis vs. frozen shoulder

 
 Shoulder osteoarthritis: Gradual stiffness over years, pain with loading,
 crepitation

 Frozen shoulder: Relatively rapid stiffness development (weeks-months),
 pronounced movement restriction in all directions, often resolves on its own

Provide a structured clinical overview of Neck Pain.

What Causes Neck Pain?: Between 80 and 90 percent of all neck pain has no specific cause detectable on X-ray or MRI. This doesn't mean the pain is imaginary - it can be very troublesome.

Cervical Radiculopathy - Nerve Root Pain: When a nerve in the neck gets pinched, it can cause radiation down the arm with tingling, numbness or weakness. This affects approximately 0.8-1.8 per 1000 people annually . The good news: 75-90% improve with conservative treatment .

Conditions That Often Accompany Neck Pain: 43% of patients with prolonged neck pain also report dizziness. The neck has a high density of position sensors - when these malfunction due to muscle tightness or joint dysfunction, a sensory conflict occurs creating dizziness.

MRI and Degeneration - "Gray Hair for the Spine": Many become worried when MRI shows "wear and tear" or "degeneration". But such findings are normal in adults and rarely explain your pain.

Treatment of Neck Pain: The combination of manual treatment and exercises has documented effect for neck pain. A 2023 meta-analysis found that manipulative therapy gave better results on pain and function compared to control groups.

Frequently Asked Questions: Most acute episodes resolve within 2-6 weeks. Improvement happens fastest in the first 6-12 weeks.

Need Help With Neck Pain?: At TheBackROM in Majorstua, I have experience with all types of neck pain - from acute torticollis to long-term problems, from nerve root pain to cervicogenic headache.

Related Articles: Learn more about neck pain through our in-depth blog articles

Describe What is FAI? for FAI - Hip Impingement.

What is FAI?

 

 FAI (Femoroacetabular Impingement), often called "hip impingement," is a
 common cause of hip pain. It is a condition where the
 shape of the hip joint leads to bone-on-bone contact in certain positions. This can
 irritate cartilage and the labrum over time.

 FAI is not a disease, but an anatomical variant. Many people have FAI
 morphology without having pain. The problem arises when this shape is combined with
 activities requiring large hip movements.

 
 
 10-15%
 of population
 

 
 20-40
 most common age
 

 
 2:1
 men vs women (cam)
 

 
 60-70%
 better without surgery
 

 

 The Three Types of FAI

 
 
 Cam Type

 A bump on the femoral head that impinges against the hip socket during flexion.
 Most common in men and athletes. Often develops during adolescence.

 

 
 Pincer Type

 The hip socket extends too far out and covers too much of the femoral head. More
 common in women. Causes the labrum to be pinched, which can develop into a labral tear.

 

 
 Mixed Type

 A combination of cam and pincer. The most common form. Approx. 70% of FAI
 patients have both.

 Meniere's disease is relatively rare with a prevalence of about 43 per 100,000. The condition causes attacks with dizziness (20 minutes to 12 hours), hearing loss, tinnitus, and pressure sensation in the ear.
