Hva forårsaker Når svimmelheten ikke passer inn: Er det BPPV eller noe annet??

De vanligste årsakene til svimmelhet - rangert

 

 
 1. BPPV/Krystallsyke (17-39% av kliniske tilfeller)

 Den vanligste vestibulære diagnosen, men altså langt fra den eneste. Livstidsprevalens i befolkningen er 2,4%, og kumulativ risiko nær omtrent 10% ved 80 års alder.

 
 Kort svimmelhet (sekunder) ved hodebevegelser

 Utløses av å legge seg ned, snu seg i sengen, se opp

 Positiv Dix-Hallpike test

 
 Obs: Opptil 41% av BPPV-pasienter har IKKE klassisk rotasjonssvimmelhet. Mange beskriver heller en "nautisk" følelse, ustadighet eller tåkethet.

 

 
 2. Vestibulær migrene (6-29% av svimmelhetspasienter)

 Den nest vanligste årsaken til tilbakevendende svimmelhet, og kraftig underdiagnostisert. Kun 10% av de som oppfyller diagnosekriteriene får vite at migrene forÅrsaker symptomene deres. Tilstanden rammer 0,98-2,7% av befolkningen generelt.

 
 Svimmelhetsepisoder som varer minutter til dager

 Hodepine, lys-/lydfølsomhet eller synsforstyrrelser i minst halvparten av anfallene

 Tidligere eller nåværende migrenehistorikk

 Migrenepasienter har tre ganger høyere risiko for å utvikle BPPV

 
 Viktig: Når reposisjonsmanøver ikke virker etter tre forsøk, bør vestibulær migrene mistenkes sterkt.

 

 
 3. PPPD - Persistent postural-perseptuell svimmelhet (15-20%)

 PPPD er den vanligste kroniske svimmelhetstilstanden hos personer mellom 30-50 år. Den utvikler seg ofte som en komplikasjon til andre vestibulære tilstander - inkludert ubehandlet BPPV.

 
 Svimmelhet/ustadighet ...

Diagnostikk

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Diagnosen stilles primært klinisk. Fem funn som støtter athletic pubalgia

 Palpasjonsomhet over skambeinsgrenen ved rectus abdominis-festet

 Smerte ved motstandstestet hofteadduksjon

 Smerte ved motstandstestet sit-up

 Ingen palpabelt lyskebrokk

 Resisted adduction sit-up test (RASUT)

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR er standard bildemodalitet ved behov for bekreftelse. MR har 68% sensitivitet og 100% spesifisitet for rectus abdominis-skade, og 86% sensitivitet og 89% spesifisitet for adduktorsene-skade.

 Viktig å huske

 MR-funn må tolkes forsiktig. Studier har vist at asymptomatiske ishockeyspillere ofte har MR-forandringer som ligner athletic pubalgia.

WAD-gradering (Quebec Task Force)

 

 
 
 
 Grad
 Beskrivelse
 
 
 
 
 WAD 0
 Ingen nakkeplager eller kliniske funn
 
 
 WAD I
 Nakkeplager (smerte, stivhet, omhet) uten kliniske funn
 
 
 WAD II
 Nakkeplager med muskuloskeletale funn (nedsatt bevegelighet, punktomhet) - vanligst (~82%)
 
 
 WAD III
 Nakkeplager med nevrologiske funn (nedsatte reflekser, svakhet, sensibilitetsutfall)

Patient asks: "What is the difference between a workplace injury and an occupational disease?"

A workplace injury is a sudden event (fall, impact, acute lifting injury). An occupational disease is caused by prolonged exposure in the work environment (for example vibration injuries). Repetitive strain injuries such as mouse arm and chronic neck pain fall in a grey area and are more difficult to get approved.

Describe diagnosis for SI Joint Problems and Pelvic Dysfunction.

Diagnosis

 SI joint pain is primarily diagnosed clinically. There is no single test that is 100% accurate, so we use
 a combination of several tests.

 Clinical Provocation Tests

 Distraction test - pressure outward on the hip bones

 Compression test - pressure inward on the hip bones

 FABER/Patrick's test - stress on the SI joint via the hip

 Thigh thrust - pressure through the thigh

 Gaenslen's test - one leg over the edge of the bed

 The 3 of 5 rule

 If 3 or more of these 5 tests are positive, there is over 90% probability that the pain originates from
 the SI joint.

 Imaging

 X-ray and MRI rarely show anything with functional SI joint problems. Imaging is most
 useful to rule out other conditions such as
 Arthritis in the SI joint

 Inflammatory disease (Ankylosing spondylitis)

 Fractures

 Infection

Symptomer ved C5-C6 prolaps

 

 Symptomene ved C5-C6 prolaps er ganske spesifikke og følger fordelingen til C6-nerven. De kan variere i intensitet fra mild nummenhet til betydelig smerte og svakhet.

 
 Typiske C6-symptomer

 
 Smerte: Straler fra nakken, ut i skulderen, nedover utsiden av overarmen til tommelen og pekefingeren

 Nummenhet/prikking: Tommel og pekefinger, noen ganger langfingeren

 Svakhet: Vansker med å bøye albuen (biceps) eller strekke handleddet

 Refleksendring: Redusert brachioradialisrefleks

 
 

 Smerteprovokasjon

 Symptomene forverres typisk ved:

 
 A vri hodet mot den affiserte siden

 Å bøye nakken bakover (ekstensjon)

 Hosting eller nysing

 A presse ned på hodet (Spurling's test)

 

 
 Bakody's tegn - lindring ved å løfte armen

 Et karakteristisk funn ved cervikal radikulopati er at smerten lindres når du legger handen på hodet. Dette reduserer strekket på nerveroten og er et nyttig diagnostisk tegn.

 

 Smertemanster gjennom dognet

 Ved cervikal radikulopati er smerten ofte verst om natten og tidlig morgen. Dette skyldes at nakken ligger i en statisk posisjon over lengre tid, og eventuell hevelse rundt nerven får tid til å akkumuleres.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Hopperkne.

Hva er hopperkne?: Hopperkne (patellar tendinopati) er en overbelastningsskade i patellasenen - senen som forbinder kneskallen med leggbeinet. Tilstanden kalles også "jumper's knee". Til forskjell fra løperkne (PFPS) som rammer selve kneleddet, er det her senen som er problemet.

Symptomer: Akutt respons på overbelastning. Senen hevner og tykkner. Ofte etter plutselig treningsøkning.

Behandling - Heavy Slow Resistance: Treningsbasert behandling er hjørnesteinen for seneplager. Heavy Slow Resistance (HSR) har vist seg minst like effektivt som eksentrisk trening.

Hva du bør UNNGA: Hvis legen foreslær kortisoninjeksjon for seneplager, spår om alternativer!

Prognose: Seneplager krever tålmodighet. Forvent 3-6 måneders rehabilitering for god effekt.

Vurder røde flagg: 42 år mann med korsryggsmerte som er verre om natten. Sover dårlig pga smerte. Smerter lindres noe ved stillingsendring. Normal appetitt, stabil vekt. Ingen tidligere sykdommer.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor nattsmerter IKKE betyr kreft her:
- Nattsmerter som BEDRES ved stillingsendring = mekanisk årsak (diskogen, fasett)
- Kreftrelaterte nattsmerter er KONSTANTE, uavhengig av stilling
- Ingen vekttap, ingen appetittendring, ingen tidligere kreft
- Alder 42 uten risikofaktorer = lav pre-test sannsynlighet for malignitet
- "Verre om natten" er vanlig ved inflammatorisk/diskogen smerte pga. økt intradiskal trykk i liggende

Klinisk bilde: Mekanisk/diskogen korsryggsmerte med nattlig komponent.

Trygt å behandle konservativt. Prøv McKenzie-vurdering for stillingspreferanse.

Describe Rib Fracture (costa fracture) in the context of Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Rib Fracture (costa fracture)

 A rib fracture occurs when one or more ribs get a crack or a complete break in the bone structure. This
 typically happens after trauma - a fall, a blow to the chest, or a car accident.

 Rib fractures are relatively common injuries. Approximately 10% of all trauma patients admitted to
 hospital have one or more rib fractures (StatPearls, 2024). In older people with osteoporosis, fractures
 can occur with much less force - sometimes just from severe coughing.

Describe How Common Are Foot Problems? for Foot and Ankle Problems.

How Common Are Foot Problems?

 

 A systematic review from 2011 analysed 31 studies with over 75,000 participants and found that
 24% of adults over 45 report frequent foot problems, and 15% have ankle
 problems. Prevalence increases with age, and women are affected more often than men.

 A large population study from North England found that foot problems in people over 55 double the
 risk of difficulties with standing and walking, and increase the risk of problems with stairs
 by 71%.

 Common Symptoms

 
 Morning stiffness: Pain and stiffness with first steps after rest

 Load-related pain: Worsening with standing, walking or running

 Swelling: Localised or diffuse around foot or ankle

 Instability: Feeling the ankle "gives way"

 Numbness or tingling: In toes or forefoot

Describe diagnosis for Osteoporosis and Compression Fractures in the Back.

Diagnosis

 Imaging

 X-ray is the first line for detecting compression fractures and shows reduced vertebral height. MRI is
 recommended when one needs to differentiate between acute and old fracture, or upon suspicion of cancer or
 infection. Acute fractures show bone marrow edema on MRI (high signal on T2/STIR sequences) - this is
 important information since regular X-ray cannot distinguish between fresh and healed fractures.

 Bone density scan (DEXA)

 WHO criteria for interpretation of T-score
 Category 
 T-score 

 Normal 
 T-score >= -1.0 

 Osteopenia (reduced bone density) 
 T-score -1.0 to -2.5 

 Osteoporosis 
 T-score 

 Severe osteoporosis 
 T-score 

 Fracture risk doubles for every standard deviation below normal. The FRAX calculator (available for
 Norway) calculates 10-year fracture risk and is used to assess treatment need.

Describe causes and risk factors for Chronic Back Pain.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Modern pain science has moved away from searching for a single cause of chronic back pain. Instead, we use what is called the biopsychosocial model . The idea is simple: pain is influenced by three factors simultaneously.

 Biological Factors

 Muscle tension, joint stiffness, deconditioning (reduced physical fitness) and sleep deprivation can all contribute to the pain persisting. Structural changes on MRI, such as wear and tear or disc bulging, are also found in pain-free individuals and rarely explain chronic pain on their own.

 Psychological Factors

 Thoughts and emotions about the pain play a significant role. Research shows that fear-avoidance and catastrophizing are among the strongest modifiable predictors of poor outcomes in back pain (Wertli et al., 2014; PAIN Reports, 2023). Thoughts such as "my back is broken" or "I don't dare to move" can amplify the pain and perpetuate the problem.

 Social Factors

 Job dissatisfaction, social isolation, financial insecurity and lack of support from those around you can all influence the pain experience. In Norway, musculoskeletal conditions are the leading cause of sick leave (STAMI/NAV, 2024), and workplace factors often play a role in the transition to chronic pain.

 The point is not that the pain is "all in your head". The point is that the brain and nervous system take into account everything happening around you, and adjust the pain volume accordingly. A systematic review with 991 participants showed that biopsychosocial interventions can reduce pain and disability in chronic back pain (ScienceDirect SR, 2023).

 Risk Factors for Chronification

 Not everyone with acute back pain develops persistent symptoms.

Describe symptoms and signs of Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain.

Symptoms

 

 Trigger points in the neck produce a characteristic symptom pattern:

 
 Local Tenderness

 A distinct point that is very tender to pressure.

 

 
 Referred Pain

 Pain radiates in a predictable pattern. Upper trapezius often causes pain toward the back of the head
 and temple. Sternocleidomastoid can cause pain around the eye and forehead.

 

 
 Stiffness and Reduced Mobility

 Difficulty turning the head or looking up.

 

 
 Headache

 80% of patients with chronic tension headache have active trigger points in the upper trapezius
 (Alonso-Blanco 2011).

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Svimmel av stress og angst - Når hjernen og balansen henger sammen.

Behandling: Hva sier forskningen?

 

 
 Kognitiv atferdsterapi (CBT) - sterkest evidens

 En metaanalyse fra 2024 undersøkte 416 pasienter fordelt på 6 randomiserte studier:

 
 CBT + standard behandling vs. standard alene: 8.17 poengs forbedring på DHI

 Angstreduksjon (GAD-7): 2.50 poeng

 Depresjonsreduksjon (PHQ-9): 2.29 poeng

 
 

 
 Vestibulær rehabilitering

 En metaanalyse fra 2025 med 522 pasienter fant at vestibulær rehabilitering gir betydelig forbedring på DHI-skår - i snitt 21.84 poeng.

 Typisk program varer 4-12 uker med 2-3 økter ukentlig og inkluderer:

 
 Blikkstabiliseringsøvelser

 Balansetrening

 Habituering til bevegelse

 Visuell desensitisering

 
 

 
 Manuell behandling ved nakkekomponent

 En randomisert studie fra 2014 (n=86) med 12 måneders oppfølging undersøkte mobiliseringsteknikker ved cervikogen svimmelhet:

 
 Passiv leddmobilisering: 13.6 poengs forbedring pa DHI

 Sustained natural apophyseal glides (SNAGs): 8.9 poengs forbedring

 
 En metaanalyse fra 2022 (13 studier, 898 pasienter) konkluderte med moderat evidens for at manuell behandling reduserer cervikogen svimmelhet og balanseproblemer.

Identifiser røde flagg for Akutt Skadehåndtering.

Hva skjer i kroppen ved en akutt skade?

 For å forstå hvorfor riktig akuttbehandling er så viktig, må vi forstå hva som skjer i vevet etter en skade. Tilhelingsprosessen følger tre overlappende faser
 Inflammasjonsfasen (0-72 timer)

 Umiddelbart etter skaden starter kroppen en betennelsesreaksjon. Blodkar utvider seg, immunceller strømmer til skadestedet, og hevelse oppstår. Du kjenner dette som smerte, hevelse, varme og rødhet . Dette er ikke en feil - det er kroppens reparasjonsmekanisme. Betennelsesceller rydder opp i skadet vev og sender signalstoffer som starter gjenoppbyggingen. Å undertrykke denne fasen fullstendig kan faktisk forsinke tilhelingen (Dubois & Esculier, 2019).

 Proliferasjonsfasen (48 timer - 6 uker)

 Kroppen begynner å bygge nytt vev. Fibroblaster produserer kollagen, nye blodkar dannes (angiogenese), og granulasjonsvev erstatter det skadede vevet. I denne fasen er kontrollert mekanisk belastning avgjørende - det styrer hvordan kollagenfibrene legger seg og gir sterkere vev (Khan & Scott, 2009).

 Remodelleringsfasen (3 uker - 12+ måneder)

 Finpussen. Svakere type III-kollagen erstattes gradvis med sterkere type I-kollagen. Vevet modnes, og full styrke kan ta opptil 12 måneder å oppnå . Nettopp derfor er rehabilitering viktig også lenge etter at smerten har gitt seg. Smertefrihet betyr ikke at du er frisk - vevet trenger tid til å modnes og styrkes gjennom progressiv belastning.

Patient asks: "Can a chiropractor treat trigeminal neuralgia?"

A chiropractor cannot treat trigeminal neuralgia itself. TN is a neurological condition that requires medical treatment with carbamazepine or surgery. There are no randomized studies supporting chiropractic treatment of TN. However, a chiropractor can differentiate TN from TMD, neck-related pain, and dental problems, treat concurrent musculoskeletal complaints, and refer to a neurologist.

Describe symptoms for Occipital Neuralgia.

Symptoms

 The typical symptoms of occipital neuralgia are characteristic and differ from other headache types
 Pain Character

 Stabbing, shooting, or burning pain

 Often described as "electric shocks"

 Starts at the neck/back of head junction and radiates upward toward the back of the head 

 Can reach all the way to the forehead or behind the eye

 Usually unilateral , but can be bilateral

 Attack Pattern

 Attacks of intense pain lasting seconds to minutes

 May have underlying aching pain between attacks

 Often triggered by head movements or touching the scalp

 Accompanying Symptoms

 Allodynia: Scalp becomes tender to touch - even light touch can hurt

 Numbness or tingling in the scalp

 Pain when brushing hair or laying head on pillow

 Light sensitivity (less common than in migraine)

 Diagnostic Test

 In occipital neuralgia, there is typically tenderness on palpation over the occipital nerve's exit point (approximately midway between the ear and the cervical vertebrae, at the lower border of the back of the head). Pressure here can reproduce or intensify symptoms.

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Kne- og leggsmerter – Komplett guide.

Behandling hos kiropraktor

 

 
 Første konsultasjon (ca. 45 minutter)

 Ved første konsultasjon får du en grundig undersøkelse med:

 
 Sykehistorie og smertekartlegging

 Fysisk undersøkelse av kne, hofte og ankel

 Vurdering av bevegelsesmønstre og muskelstyrke

 Eventuell henvisning til bildediagnostikk hvis nødvendig

 
 

 Behandlingen tilpasses din tilstand og kan inkludere: leddmobilisering, bløtvevsbehandling, tøyning, dry needling, trykkbølgebehandling (for seneplager), og ikke minst å et individuelt Øvelsesprogram.

 
 HjemmeØvelser å nåkkelen til bedring

 Øvelser du gjør selv mellom behandlingene er avgjørende for resultatet. Typiske fokusområder:

 
 Quadriceps-styrke: Knebøy, utfall, step-ups

 Hoftemuskulatur: Gluteus-Øvelser, sideliggende beinhev, bridging

 Balanse og propriosepsjon: Ettbeins-stående, balansebrett

 Tøyning: Quadriceps, hamstrings, leggmuskulatur

 
 

 
 Realistiske forventninger

 De fleste kne- og leggplager responderer godt på konservativ behandling. Typisk behandlingsforløp varierer fra 2-4 uker for enkle overbelastningsskader til 8-12 uker for mer komplekse tilstander. Noen tilstander, som artrose, krever langvarig egenbehandling. Tilbakefall kan forekomme, og vedlikeholdstrening er ofte nødvendig.

Describe causes and risk factors for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Causes and risk factors

 Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when pressure in the tunnel becomes too high. This can be caused by
 Swelling of the tendons (most common)

 Repetitive strain or overuse can cause swelling in the tendon sheaths passing through the tunnel,
 reducing space for the nerve.

 Hormonal factors

 Pregnancy, menopause, hypothyroidism and diabetes increase risk through fluid retention and tissue
 swelling.

 Anatomical factors

 Some people naturally have narrower carpal tunnels. Previous wrist fractures can also narrow the
 tunnel.

 Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm .

 Important risk factors

 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

Describe diagnosis for Dysautonomia.

Diagnosis

 Active Standing Test

 The simplest test: measure heart rate and blood pressure lying down, then after 2, 5, and 10 minutes in a standing position. A heart rate increase of 30 beats/min or more without significant blood pressure drop raises suspicion of POTS. This test can be performed at a GP's office or by a chiropractor.

 Tilt-Table Test

 The gold standard for POTS diagnosis. The patient is secured to a table that tilts to 60-70 degrees, with continuous monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure for up to 45 minutes. Available at larger hospitals.

 Blood Tests and Exclusion

 Thyroid disease, adrenal insufficiency, anemia, and other conditions that can produce similar symptoms must be ruled out. ECG and possibly Holter monitoring exclude primary heart disease.

 When should you suspect dysautonomia?

 Dizziness that consistently worsens upon standing

 Heart palpitations without known heart disease

 Pronounced fatigue without explanation after standard workup

 Symptom worsening in heat, after meals, or with prolonged standing

 Symptoms that started after a viral infection (including COVID-19)

 Red Flags - Seek medical help immediately for
 Repeated fainting without warning

 Fainting during physical exertion

 Chest pain with breathing difficulties

 Rapidly progressing neurological symptoms

 Seizures in connection with fainting

 Call emergency services for acute, severe symptoms.

Hva er triggerfinger?

 

 Triggerfinger (stenoserende tenosynovitt) oppstar når bøyesenen i fingeren blir for tykk til å gli fritt gjennom seneskjeden. Senen "henger seg opp" ved A1-pulleyet ved fingerroten, og fingeren lasser seg i bøyd stilling. En lignende mekanisme ses ved De Quervains tenosynovitt i tommelen.

 Typiske symptomer

 Tidlig fase

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for PIFP: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er PIFP?

 PIFP (Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte) er vedvarende ansiktssmerte som varer mer enn 2 timer daglig i over 3 måneder, uten identifiserbar Årsak. Det er en eksklusjonsdiagnose som stilles når andre Årsaker er utelukket.

 

 
 Kan PIFP kureres?

 PIFP er ofte en kronisk tilstand, men de fleste oppnår betydelig bedring med riktig behandling. Målet er smertelindring og forbedret livskvalitet, ikke nødvendigvis fullstendig smertefrihet.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen mellom PIFP og trigeminal nevralgi?

 Trigeminal nevralgi gir korte, intense smerteattakker (sekunder til minutter) langs trigeminusnervens baner. PIFP gir vedvarende, dov smerte som ikke følger nerveanatomi og mangler de skarpe attackene.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe ved PIFP?

 Kiropraktoren kan bidra til å utelukke TMD og behandle eventuelle medfølgende nakke- eller kjevekomponenter. PIFP responderer imidlertid ofte ikke godt på manuell behandling alene og krever vanligvis tverrfaglig tilnærming.

 

 
 Hvorfor får jeg ikke diagnose etter mange undersøkelser?

 PIFP er en eksklusjonsdiagnose som krever at andre Årsaker utelukkes først. Dette kan ta tid og mange undersøkelser. Mange pasienter har vårt hos flere spesialister får de får riktig diagnose.

 

 
 Er smerten min "innbilt"?

 Nei, PIFP er en reell biologisk smertetilstand med forandringer i nervesystemets smerteprosessering. At vi ikke finner en strukturell Årsak betyr ikke at smerten ikke er ekte.

 

 
 Bør je...

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Describe causes - from most to least common for Dizzy When Standing Up.

Causes - From Most to Least Common

 1. Orthostatic Hypotension (Blood Pressure Drop When Rising)

 This is the most common cause overall, accounting for around 42% of all dizziness cases. When you stand up, 500-1000 ml of blood collects in your legs due to gravity. Normally, the body compensates by increasing heart rate and constricting blood vessels. In orthostatic hypotension, these mechanisms fail, and the brain temporarily receives too little blood.

 Who is most affected? Elderly over 65, people taking blood pressure medication, diabetics (24% prevalence), and Parkinson's patients (30-40% prevalence).

 Typical symptoms: Lightheadedness and unsteadiness occurring seconds to minutes after standing up. Many experience "graying out" or tunnel vision. Symptoms disappear when sitting down again. Important: Symptoms never occur when lying flat.

 2. BPPV (Crystal Disease)

 BPPV is the most common vestibular cause of position-related dizziness. Around 2.4% of the population experiences this during their lifetime, and the condition accounts for 17-42% of all dizziness consultations. Women are affected twice as often as men.

 BPPV occurs when small calcium crystals in the inner ear become dislodged and end up in the semicircular canals. This sends false rotation signals to the brain.

 Typical symptoms: Intense sensation of the room spinning. Episodes typically last 10-60 seconds and are triggered by head movements - including when turning over in bed. Nausea is common.

 3. Medication Side Effects

 Over 250 medications can cause orthostatic hypotension. The main culprits include
 Alpha blockers carry highest risk

 Tricyclic antidepressants give six times increased risk

 Diuretics

 All types of blood pressure medication

 Prevalence by Age Group

 Age Group 
 Prevalence 

 Under 50 years 
 ~5% 

 60+ years 
 22% 

 Over 70 years 
 30% 

 Nursing home residents 
 24-50%

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Tekstnakke og Mobilnakke - Nakkesmerter fra Skjermbruk.

Behandling

 

 
 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 En systematisk gjennomgang fra 2023 fant at kombinasjonen av manuell terapi og stabiliseringsøvelser ga bedre resultater enn trening alene for pasienter med forward head posture og kroniske nakkesmerter.

 
 Leddmobilisering og manipulasjon: Behandling av stive ledd i nakke og øvre rygg

 Bløtvevsbehandling: Behandling av stram og overbelastet muskulatur

 Øvelsesinstruksjon: Målrettede øvelser for å styrke de dype nakkefleksorene

 Ergonomisk veiledning: Konkrete råd om skjermhøyde, stol, arbeidsstilling og pauserutiner

 
 

 
 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 
 Juster skjermhøyden: Skjermen bør være i øyehøyde. Bruk stativ for nettbrett og laptop.

 Ta hyppige pauser: Følg 20-20-20-regelen: Hvert 20. minutt, se på noe 20 meter unna i 20 sekunder.

 Chin tucks (hakeinntrykk): Trekk haken rett bakover som om du lager "dobbelhake", hold 5-10 sekunder, og gjenta 10 ganger.

 Strekk bryst- og nakkemuskulatur: Strekk pectoralis og øvre trapezius daglig.

 
 

 
 Studier på forward head posture viser at treningsprogrammer typisk varer 4-10 uker med gode resultater. For akutte tekstnakkeplager ser jeg ofte bedring innen 2-4 uker med behandling og egeninnsats.

Explain PCL Injury to a patient.

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is the strongest ligament in the knee, yet it's much less
 talked about than the ACL . PCL injuries are less common but can occur
 with direct trauma to the shin or a fall on a bent knee.

 The good news? Most isolated PCL injuries can be treated without surgery. The knee
 often adapts well, and many return to high activity levels with rehabilitation. PCL injury is one of
 the less common causes of knee pain .

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Acute Back Pain (Lumbago) - Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does acute back pain last?

 Most experience significant improvement within 2-4 weeks. About 90% are
 symptom-free within 6-8 weeks. With proper treatment and guidance, many can experience relief within
 the first few days.

 

 
 Should I rest with acute back pain?

 Bed rest is not recommended. Research shows that early, gentle movement provides
 faster recovery than strict rest. Normal daily activities (as much as pain allows) promote healing.
 

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI for acute back pain?

 For uncomplicated acute back pain, imaging is rarely necessary. Studies show
 that findings on MRI often do not correlate with symptoms. Imaging is appropriate for red flags or
 persistent symptoms beyond 6-8 weeks without improvement.

 

 
 Can I work with acute back pain?

 Many can work in modified capacity during recovery. Research supports that
 staying active and working (as much as possible) provides better long-term outcomes than complete sick
 leave.

 

 
 When should I see a doctor or emergency room?

 Contact a doctor immediately for: problems with urination/bowel function
 combined with numbness in the genital area (cauda equina), back pain with fever and weight loss,
 recent severe trauma, or progressive weakness in the legs.

 

 
 Can acute back pain be prevented?

 While acute episodes cannot always be prevented, regular physical activity, core
 muscle training, and good lifting techniques significantly reduce the risk...

Provide a structured clinical overview of Jumper's Knee.

What is Jumper's Knee?: Jumper's knee (patellar tendinopathy) is an overuse injury in the patellar tendon - the tendon that
 connects the kneecap to the shinbone. The condition is also called "jumper's knee." Unlike runner's knee (PFPS) which affects the joint itself, here it's the tendon
 that's the problem.

Symptoms: Acute response to overload. The tendon swells and thickens. Often after sudden training increase.

Treatment - Heavy Slow Resistance: Exercise-based treatment is the cornerstone for tendon problems. Heavy Slow Resistance (HSR) has proven
 at least as effective as eccentric training.

What You Should AVOID: If your doctor suggests a cortisone injection for tendon problems, ask about
 alternatives!

Prognosis: Tendon problems require patience. Expect 3-6 months of rehabilitation for good effect.

Differential diagnoses for Cervical Disc Herniation and Pinched Nerve in the Neck?

Spondylosis and foraminal stenosis (68-75%)

 Age-related changes gradually lead to narrowing of the opening where the nerve passes. Dominant cause
 in people over 50.

Disc herniation (20-25%)

 Acute bulging of the intervertebral disc pressing on the nerve root. Most common in younger patients

Injury/trauma (~15%)

 Whiplash -type injuries or other neck trauma.

Myofascial trigger points

 Active trigger points in the upper trapezius occur in 30-40% of patients with chronic neck pain . Causes radiation that can mimic radiculopathy.

Beskriv Hva er PPPD? for Kronisk Svimmelhet og PPPD.

Hva er PPPD?

 

 PPPD star for Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness, på norsk: Persisterende Postural-Perseptuell Svimmelhet. Tilstanden ble formelt definert av Børény Society i 2017 og er nå inkludert i WHOs internasjonale sykdomsklassifikasjon (ICD-11 kode AB32.0).

 PPPD er en funksjonell lidelse. Det betyr at problemet ikke ligger i selve balanseorganet - Øret og nervene fungerer ofte helt normalt ved testing. Problemet ligger i hvordan hjernen prosesserer og reagerer på signalene den mottar. Dette skiller PPPD fra tilstander som vestibulær hypofunksjon, der det er målbar skade på balanseorganet.

 
 
 15-20%
 av svimmelhetspasienter
 

 
 30-50 Ør
 vanligst aldersgruppe
 

 
 4:1

Describe Typical Symptoms of Subtle BPPV in the context of Subtle BPPV: When Dizziness Doesn't Spin.

Typical Symptoms of Subtle BPPV

 
 A vague nausea or "seasickness on land"

 Fatigue that can't be explained by lack of sleep

 Brain fog and concentration problems

 A feeling that something is "wrong," without being able to pinpoint it

 Mild unsteadiness, especially when turning around or looking up

 
 

 Harmat and colleagues' study from 2022 estimated that about one in three BPPV patients has this Type 2 variant.

 

 
 
 2
 Why Standard Examination Misses These Patients

 

 Standard examination for BPPV - the Dix-Hallpike test - is typically performed in normal lighting, where the patient can fixate their gaze. This suppresses the characteristic eye movements (nystagmus).

 
 
 
 Examination Conditions
 Proportion of Nystagmus Detected
 
 
 
 Normal room lighting40%
 Frenzel goggles, light on66%
 Frenzel goggles, darkness83%
 Videonystagmography (VNG) in darkness100%
 
 
 
 Important to Know

 Examination in normal lighting misses about 60% of eye movements that would be visible with proper equipment.

Describe symptoms and signs of Red Flags for Neck Pain - When to See a Doctor.

Symptoms of CAD

 

 The most common symptom is headache and/or neck pain (65-95% of
 patients). But CAD-related pain has characteristics that distinguish it from common muscle problems:

 
 Warning Signs of CAD

 
 Sudden onset: Pain comes abruptly, often over minutes

 One-sided: 74% have pain on the same side as the dissection (Thomas et al., 2023)
 

 "Different from anything else": 75% describe the pain as unlike any previous
 headache (Mayer-Suess et al., 2022)

 Does not respond to treatment: Pain does not ease with movement, position, or
 painkillers

 Cannot be reproduced: Examination of the neck does not provoke the pain

 
 

 Neurological Signs of CAD

 
 Horner's syndrome (25-44%): Constricted pupil and drooping eyelid on one side

 Cranial nerve involvement (12%): Tongue deviation, hoarseness, swallowing
 difficulties

 Pulsatile tinnitus (8-10%): Rhythmic sound in ear synchronous with pulse

 

 
 The Critical Time Window

 Data from Biousse et al. (Stroke 1995) showed that 82% of strokes occur within 7 days
 after symptoms started. This means early recognition can prevent stroke.

Beskriv De to hovedvariantene for Horisontal Kanal BPPV.

De to hovedvariantene

 

 
 Geotropisk variant (60-70%)

 Krystallene flyter fritt i den bakre delen av kanalen. Når du snur hodet til en side, beveger krystallene seg mot bakken. Svimmelheten er typisk sterkest når du ligger på den affiserte siden. Dette er den vanligste og enkleste varianten å behandle.

 

 
 Apogeotropisk variant (30-40%)

 Krystallene ligger enten i den fremre delen av kanalen når ampullaen, eller de sitter fast på sansecellene (cupulolithiasis). Øyebevegelsene slær bort fra bakken. Det forvirrende er at svimmelheten ofte er sterkest på den friske siden. Behandlingen er mer utfordrende.

Assess red flags: 43-year-old male with mechanical thoracic back pain after skydiving 2 days ago. Pain between shoulder blades. Reproducible with rotation and palpation. Normal breathing, normal SpO2. No neurological symptoms.

URGENCY: MONITOR

No acute red flags, but NOTE: skydiving = significant axial loading.

Clinical reasoning:
- Pain is reproducible = mechanical component confirmed
- Normal breathing and SpO2 = no pneumothorax/pulmonary pathology
- No neurological symptoms = no cord compression
- BUT: skydiving = significant axial loading at landing
- Compression fracture can have subtle initial presentation

- Palpate each segment for focal percussion tenderness (vs. diffuse muscular soreness)
- If ANY focal tenderness over spinous process → X-ray

Prevention

 Mouthguard - First Line of Defense

 A good mouthguard reduces the risk of jaw injuries by 80-90% 
 Types of Mouthguards

 Standard ("boil and bite"): Cheap, poor fit, least protection

 Custom-fitted by dentist: Best fit, best protection, more expensive

 Semi-custom: Middle ground, good value

 Important Features

 Covers all teeth properly

 Fits well without falling out

 Allows breathing through the mouth

 Investment That Pays Off

 A custom mouthguard costs 2,000-4,000 NOK, but can save you thousands in dental treatment and jaw problems. Consider it part of your equipment budget.

 Technique and Training

 Learn to take hits: Tuck your chin, don't tense muscles excessively

 Strengthen neck muscles: Better support for the jaw

 Tap out in time: Give up before injury occurs in grappling

 Gradual progression: Don't spar too hard too early

 Training Routines

 Avoid hard sparring the day after jaw problems

 Take rest days between heavy sessions

 Vary between technique training and sparring

Describe diagnosis for Shoulder Impingement.

Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is primarily made through history and clinical examination. Imaging is rarely necessary in uncomplicated cases.

 Clinical tests

 Neer's test

 The arm is passively lifted straight forward with internal rotation. Positive when pain occurs at end range. Sensitivity 75-89% , but specificity only 25-31% (Hegedus et al. 2012). The test catches most cases of impingement but also produces many false positives.

 Hawkins-Kennedy test

 The arm is held in 90 degrees of flexion, and the forearm is rotated inward. Positive when pain occurs. Sensitivity 80-90% , specificity 25-50% (Hegedus et al. 2012). Considered the most sensitive single test.

 Painful arc

 The patient actively lifts the arm out to the side. Pain between 60-120 degrees is positive. This test has somewhat better specificity than Neer and Hawkins alone.

 The tests are not perfect

 No single test can confirm or rule out impingement with certainty. Low specificity (25-50%) means that many with a positive test do not necessarily have impingement. The overall clinical picture - history, all tests combined, and the pain pattern - provides the best assessment.

 Differential diagnoses

 Several conditions can cause similar symptoms
 Calcific tendinitis - calcium deposits in the rotator cuff

 Frozen shoulder - stiffness of the joint capsule

 AC joint osteoarthritis - wear in the acromioclavicular joint

 Biceps tendinopathy - tendon problems in the biceps

 Cervical radiculopathy - nerve root pain from the neck

 Imaging

 Imaging is usually not necessary to make the diagnosis or initiate treatment. Ultrasound or MRI may be considered if there is no improvement after 6-8 weeks, suspected rotator cuff tear, or an unclear clinical picture. X-ray can rule out calcific deposits or osteoarthritis.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Red Flags for Back Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How do I know if my back pain is dangerous?

 Most back pain is harmless. Watch for combinations of symptoms: Back pain alone
 without other symptoms is rarely serious. It's when back pain is combined with bladder dysfunction,
 groin numbness, unexplained weight loss, fever, or rapidly progressive weakness that you should seek
 prompt help.

 

 
 Can a chiropractor detect serious illness?

 Yes. Norwegian chiropractors are licensed healthcare professionals with 5-6 years
 of education. A thorough clinical examination with neurological testing is often more informative than
 imaging. When serious pathology is suspected, the chiropractor has a duty to refer further.

 

 
 How quickly does cauda equina syndrome develop?

 It varies. Some experience gradual worsening over days to weeks, others get sudden
 symptoms. If you have established back pain and develop new symptoms like bladder dysfunction or groin
 numbness, you should seek help immediately.

Beskriv symptomer for Rotator Cuff — Komplett Guide til Rotatorkuffen.

Symptomer

 Symptomene varierer avhengig av skadetype, storrelse og om det er en akutt eller gradvis utvikling.

 Typiske symptomer

 Smerte ved armbruk: Spesielt ved loft av armen ut til siden eller over hodet

 Painful arc: Smerter mellom 60-120 graders loft (klassisk tegn)

 Nattsmerter: Ofte det symptomet som plager mest. Vanskelig a ligge pa den vonde skulderen

 Svakhet: Kan merkes som vanskeligheter med a holde armen oppe eller lofte gjenstander

 Krepitasjon: Knitring eller klikking ved bevegelse

 Akutt traumatisk ruptur

 Sok hjelp raskt 

 Plutselig, kraftig smerte etter fall eller loft

 Umiddelbar svakhet — kan ikke lofte armen

 Ofte en folelse av at noe «rives» eller «knekker»

 Rask hovelse og blamerker

 Gradvis (degenerativ) debut

 Vanligst 

 Sniknede start uten tydelig utlosende hendelse

 Gradvis okende smerter over uker til maneder

 Ofte verre om natten og nar du hviler pa skulderen

 Svakheten kan vare mild og nesten umerkelig i starten

Describe Risk factors in the context of SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Repetitive overhead activity

 Main cause
 

 Throwing movements and overhead sports expose the biceps attachment to repeated pulling forces. Over
 time, this can lead to SLAP lesion. Common in:

 
 Handball players (see thrower's shoulder)

 Volleyball players

 Baseball pitchers

 Swimmers

 Tennis players

 
 

 Risk factors

 
 Overhead sports, especially throwing sports

 Age 20-40 years for traumatic lesions

 Age over 40 for degenerative changes (type I)

 Glenohumeral internal rotation deficit (GIRD)

 Weak scapula control

 Previous shoulder instability

 

 
 Important perspective

 Many have SLAP lesions on MRI without symptoms. A study found that up to 55% of asymptomatic
 shoulders in people over 45 years had labrum changes. This means an MRI finding does not necessarily
 explain your pain.

Describe treatment options for Text Neck and Phone Neck - Neck Pain from Screen Use.

Treatment

 

 
 What can the chiropractor do?

 A systematic review from 2023 found that the combination of manual therapy and stabilization exercises gave better results than training alone for patients with forward head posture and chronic neck pain.

 
 Joint mobilization and manipulation: Treatment of stiff joints in neck and upper back

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight and overloaded musculature

 Exercise instruction: Targeted exercises to strengthen the deep neck flexors

 Ergonomic guidance: Concrete advice about screen height, chair, work position and break routines

 
 

 
 What can you do yourself?

 
 Adjust screen height: The screen should be at eye level. Use stands for tablet and laptop.

 Take frequent breaks: Follow the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 meters away for 20 seconds.

 Chin tucks: Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin", hold 5-10 seconds, and repeat 10 times.

 Stretch chest and neck muscles: Stretch pectoralis and upper trapezius daily.

 
 

 
 Studies on forward head posture show that exercise programs typically last 4-10 weeks with good results. For acute text neck problems, I often see improvement within 2-4 weeks with treatment and self-effort.

What is the prognosis for Vestibular Neuritis?

Prognosis

 

 Vestibular neuritis is a self-limiting condition with generally good prognosis:

 
 
 2-3 weeks
 significant improvement
 

 
 3-6 mo
 full compensation
 

 
 50-70%
 full recovery
 

 

 
 Most experience significant improvement within 2-3 weeks

 Full compensation (can run, turn quickly without problems) can take 3-6 months

 Approximately 50-70% achieve full or near-full recovery

 30-50% develop persistent, milder dizziness

 

 
 Interesting Finding

 Long-term prognosis does not depend on how much nerve function is restored. Even if caloric testing still shows significant asymmetry, patients can become completely symptom-free because the brain compensates effectively.

 

 Factors Predicting Poorer Recovery:

 
 High degree of anxiety at disease onset

 Strong visual dependency (relying too much on vision for balance)

 Avoidance behavior (lying still for too long)

 Prolonged use of vestibular suppressants

 
 In some cases, persistent symptoms can develop into PPPD (persistent postural-perceptual dizziness), especially with strong anxiety or avoidance behavior. Patients with vestibular migraine may also have increased risk for poorer outcomes.

 Risk of Recurrence

 
 Recurrence in the same ear is rare - the nerve is often permanently damaged

 Risk of getting it in the other ear is approximately 2-4% over a lifetime

Differential diagnoses for Headache on Top of the Head?

Tension Headache

 Most common - 46% lifetime 

 Tension headache is by far the most common cause of headache on top of the head. Lifetime prevalence is 46% globally, and Danish studies show up to 78%. Women are affected twice as often as men.

 Typical presentation is bilateral, pressing or tightening pain - often described as a "band around the head" that can focus on the top. The pain is mild to moderate and does not worsen with physical activity.

 Risk factors: Stress, poor sleep, prolonged screen work and static work postures.

Trigger Points in Neck Musculature

 Referred pain 

 Muscles in the neck can refer pain to the top of the head through a phenomenon called "referred pain." Read more about trigger points and headache .

 Splenius capitis is the primary muscle that sends pain specifically to the crown. Trigger points in this muscle - located approximately at the C3 level - create a characteristic pain sensation in a 3-5 cm zone in the middle of the top of the head. Patients often describe this as "internal head pain" or "pressure on the crown."

 Suboccipital muscles (the small muscles at the very top of the neck) are found to have active trigger points in 65% of patients with chronic tension headache. These muscles have a direct anatomical connection to the meninges.

Cervicogenic Headache

 2.5-4.1% of population 

 Cervicogenic headache is caused by dysfunction in the upper cervical vertebrae (C1-C3) and surrounding structures. The Norwegian Vaga study found 4.1% prevalence.

 This type of headache typically starts in the neck and radiates upward toward the top of the head on one side. The pain worsens with neck movements and sustained postures.

Occipital Neuralgia

 Rare 

 Occipital neuralgia causes sharp, shooting pain from the back of the head that can radiate to the top of the head. The pain follows the course of the occipital nerve and is often unilateral with periods of intense "lightning-like" pain.

Medication Overuse Headache

 0.5-7.
